column1: Questions
column2: Answers
column3: Context Info

column1: What is the scope of the technical specification mentioned in the document?
column2: The scope of the technical specification is defined in Section 1, and it covers restoration procedures within the 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) for Core Network and Terminals, Release 18.
column3: The technical specification, titled "3GPP TS 23.007 V18.2.0 (2023-06)," is a document developed within the 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP). It falls under the Technical Specification Group Core Network and Terminals and specifically focuses on "Restoration procedures" as part of Release 18.The document outlines various aspects related to restoration procedures within the 3GPP framework. It covers a wide range of topics, including restoration indicators in different network elements such as VLR, HLR, SGSN, MME, ProSe Function, and V2X Control Function. Additionally, it details specific procedures for the restoration of data in various components like VLR, HLR/HSS, GGSN, SGSN, MME, GERAN/UTRAN, E-UTRAN, SGW, PGW, and more.The specifications provided in this document are crucial for future development work within the 3GPP, and it emphasizes that it has not undergone any approval process by the 3GPP Organizational Partners. The document also includes contact information for the 3GPP support office and copyright notification.Feel free to ask for more specific details or if you have any particular areas of interest within the document.

column1: Where can specifications and reports for the implementation of the 3GPP TM system be obtained?
column2: Specifications and reports for the implementation of the 3GPP TM system should be obtained via the 3GPP Organizational Partners' Publications Offices, as mentioned in the document.

column1: What are the different restoration indicators discussed in the document?
column2: The document discusses various restoration indicators in different network elements, including the VLR, HLR, SGSN, MME, ProSe Function, and V2X Control Function.

column1: What procedures are outlined for the restoration of data in the VLR after a failure?
column2: Procedures for the restoration of data in the VLR after a failure are detailed in Section 4 of the document. It covers scenarios like VLR Failure with Restart and VLR Failure without Restart.

column1: In which section can information about the restoration of data in the GGSN be found?
column2: Information about the restoration of data in the GGSN is provided in Section 10 of the document.

column1: What is discussed in Section 16.2 regarding the SGW?
column2: Section 16.2 discusses partial failure handling at the SGW, outlining general procedures during PDN Connection Establishment and actions during SGW Partial Failure.

column1: Where can details about the GTP-C based restart procedures be found?
column2: Details about GTP-C based restart procedures are provided in Section 18 of the document.

column1: What is the purpose of Section 23 in the document?
column2: Section 23 outlines general partial failure handling procedures in the network.

column1: What are the abbreviations used in the document?
column2: The abbreviations listed in 3GPP TR 21.905 [1] apply for the document.
column3: This document, based on 3GPP TR 21.905, outlines specifications related to the restoration procedures for mobile networks. The document covers various aspects, including abbreviations, definitions, design objectives, and restoration indicators in location registers and GPRS support nodes. It emphasizes the importance of data security, providing procedures to secure data and ensure integrity during potential failures. Key components include the HLR/HSS or CSS, VLR, and IMSI records. Restoration indicators play a crucial role in confirming subscriber data, radio contact, and location information. The restoration process involves erasing affected IMSI records, triggering restoration procedures upon specific requests, and handling call setup requests based on the confirmed status of subscriber data. The document aims to establish a robust regime for network restoration, minimizing data loss and ensuring network reliability.

column1: What is the definition of "PDN Connection" in this specification?
column2: PDN Connection in this specification refers only to the PDN connection through the SGW and PGW.

column1: What is the purpose of the restoration indicators in the VLR?
column2: The restoration indicators in the VLR are designed to handle traffic for each mobile subscriber correctly after a failure, ensuring consistency with subscriber data in the HLR or CSS and reflecting accurate location information.

column1: How does the VLR handle a failure without restart?
column2: If the VLR serving a mobile station (MS) for non-GPRS services is no longer in service, the SGSN may perform an immediate location update for non-GPRS services towards an alternative VLR.

column1: What happens when a VLR restarts after a failure?
column2: When a VLR restarts after a failure, all IMSI records affected by the failure are erased, and no subscriber data or location information is stored for an affected mobile station until a "Provide Roaming Number" or "Update Location Area" request is received.

column1: What triggers restoration of subscriber data in the VLR?
column2: Restoration of subscriber data in the VLR is triggered individually for each IMSI record upon receiving either a "Provide Roaming Number" or an "Update Location Area" request for the affected mobile station.

column1: How does the VLR handle an incoming call during restoration?
column2: During an incoming call, the VLR returns an MSRN regardless of whether an IMSI record exists. If no IMSI record exists, the VLR creates a skeleton IMSI record, sets specific indicators, and returns the MSRN.

column1: What is the role of the "Check SS" indicator in the HLR?
column2: The "Check SS" indicator in the HLR is set to "Check Required" when the HLR restarts after a failure. It is checked when the HLR receives an "Update Location" request, and if required, a "Forward Check SS Indication" request is sent to the VLR.

column1: How does the SGSN handle the "VLR-Reliable" indicator?
column2: The "VLR-Reliable" indicator is set to "false" when the SGSN receives a Reset indication message from the VLR serving the MS. It is set to "true" upon confirmation from a VLR that a location update procedure to the affected VLR has been successfully performed.

column1: What is the purpose of the restoration indicator "Subscriber Data Confirmed by HSS" in the MME?
column2: The "Subscriber Data Confirmed by HSS" indicator in the MME indicates whether the subscriber data set for the mobile station held by the MME is consistent with that held by the HSS.

column1: What abbreviations apply for the purposes of this document?
column2: The abbreviations listed in 3GPP TR 21.905 [1] apply.

column1: What is the definition of "PDN Connection" in this specification?
column2: PDN Connection in this specification only refers to the PDN connection through the SGW and PGW.

column1: What is the term that takes precedence over the definition in TR 21.905 [1]?
column2: A term defined in this document takes precedence over the definition in TR 21.905 [1].

column1: What are the design objectives mentioned in Section 2?
column2: The design objectives include implementing a regime to secure data, avoiding loss of data during location register equipment failure, and providing procedures for data integrity in case of failure.

column1: According to the Technical Specification, what should the HLR/HSS or CSS perform for data security?
column2: Periodic back-up of data to non-volatile storage is mandatory for HLR/HSS or CSS.

column1: What are the three restoration indicators provided in the VLR for each IMSI record?
column2: The three indicators are "Confirmed by Radio Contact," "Subscriber Data Confirmed by HLR," and "Location Information Confirmed in HLR."

column1: When is the "Confirmed by Radio Contact" indicator set to "Confirmed"?
column2: The indicator is set to "Confirmed" when the radio contact with the mobile station is authenticated.

column1: What events trigger the setting of "Location Information Confirmed in HLR" to "Not Confirmed"?
column2: Events include receiving "Update Location Area" request for an MS with no IMSI record, receiving a "Reset" message from the HLR, and more.

column1: What happens when a VLR restarts after a failure?
column2: All IMSI records affected by the failure are erased, and no subscriber data or location information is stored until the VLR receives a "Provide Roaming Number" or "Update Location Area" request.

column1: What does the VLR do when it receives a "Provide Roaming Number" request?
column2: The VLR returns an MSRN, creates a skeleton IMSI record if needed, and triggers restoration procedures.

column1: How does the VLR handle an incoming call setup request when the subscriber data is not confirmed by the HLR?
column2: The VLR returns a "System Failure" error.

column1: What information does the HLR return to the MSC in response to "Send Routing Information for MT SMS" from SMS-GMSC?
column2: The HLR returns the MSC number as for normal operation.
column3: The provided text discusses various procedures and protocols related to mobile communications, specifically focusing on Mobile Terminated Short Message handling and Mobile Terminating Location Requests in the context of telecommunications infrastructure. It covers processes such as sending information for mobile-terminated SMS, handling call setup requests, location requests, and restoration procedures in the Visitor Location Register (VLR) during different scenarios. Additionally, it outlines steps for restoration of data in the Home Location Register (HLR)/Home Subscriber Server (HSS) after a restart, emphasizing the collaboration between various network elements. The text is technical and pertains to the GSM and MAP (Mobile Application Part) versions 1 and 2.

column1: What actions does the VLR take for MT SMS if there's no IMSI record or the record is marked "Subscriber Data Not Confirmed by HLR"?
column2: The VLR returns an "Unidentified Subscriber" error, triggering a short message delivery failure report to the SMS gateway MSC.

column1: How does the VLR handle MT SMS for an IMSI record marked "Subscriber Data Confirmed by HLR" and "Not Confirmed by Radio Contact"?
column2: The VLR performs the data restoration procedure as specified in clause 4.2.1 for an incoming call and delays the mobile terminating SMS until the restoration is complete.

column1: What does the VLR do if there's no IMSI record or the record is marked "Subscriber Data Not Confirmed by HLR" for MT-LR?
column2: The VLR returns an "Unidentified Subscriber" error, causing the MSC to report a location failure to the GMLC.

column1: How does the VLR handle an incoming BSSMAP-LE LMU Connection Request for an LMU with no IMSI record or "Subscriber Data Not Confirmed by HLR"?
column2: The VLR returns an "Unidentified Subscriber" error for the LMU.

column1: What actions does the VLR take for an incoming BSSMAP-LE LMU Connection Request for an LMU with no IMSI record or "Subscriber Data Not Confirmed by HLR"?
column2: The VLR returns an "Unidentified Subscriber" error for the LMU.

column1: How does the VLR handle an incoming LCS Information Request if the MS responds to paging?
column2: The VLR sends a positive response to the search request and a "Process Access Request" to the VLR after successful authentication.

column1: What actions does the HLR take during restart for subscriber data affected by a fault?
column2: The HLR reloads all data from the non-volatile backup, resets "MS Purged" flags, marks each subscriber record "SS Check Required," and sends reset messages to associated VLRs, SGSNs, MMEs, ProSe Functions, and V2X Control Functions.

column1: How does the VLR handle a "Process Access Request" request during restoration for a mobile-terminated call?
column2: The VLR triggers an "Update Location" to the HLR if the indicator "Location Information Confirmed in HLR" is not confirmed.

column1: What does the HLR check if the "Forward Check SS Indication" service is implemented during restoration?
column2: The HLR checks the indicator "Check SS" and, if required, sends a "Forward Check SS Indication" to the VLR.

column1: What actions does the VLR take for an outgoing request from the MS if there's no IMSI record or "Subscriber Data Not Confirmed by HLR"?
column2: The outgoing request is rejected with an error cause "Unidentified Subscriber," initiating the location registration procedure.

column1: How does the VLR handle an outgoing request for LCS from a Type A LMU with no IMSI record or "Subscriber Data Not Confirmed by HLR"?
column2: The outgoing request is rejected with an error cause "Unidentified Subscriber" for the LMU.

column1: What does the VLR do during location updating or IMSI attach for an MS that is unknown in the VLR?
column2: The VLR creates a skeleton IMSI record for the MS, sets various indicators to "Not Confirmed," and performs authentication if required.

column1: What happens to the TMSI known by the MS after the VLR has restarted?
column2: The TMSI known by the MS is invalid, and the VLR uses the IMSI to identify the MS on the first radio contact during restoration.

column1: How does the VLR proceed if an MS identifies itself by a TMSI in a "Location Registration" request?
column2: The VLR checks the TMSI's status and proceeds based on whether it was allocated after VLR restart or corresponds to a valid IMSI record.

column1: How are associations with the VLR marked by SGSNs and MMEs during restoration?
column2: Reset messages are sent, marking all associations with the VLR as unreliable by setting the restoration indicator "VLR-Reliable" to "False."

column1: What mandatory action does the HLR perform during restart for subscriber data records affected by the HLR/HSS fault?
column2: The HLR reloads all data from the non-volatile backup, resets "MS Purged" flags, and sends reset messages to associated entities.

column1: How does the HLR proceed if the "Forward Check SS Indication" service is implemented during restoration?
column2: The HLR checks the "Check SS" indicator, sends a "Forward Check SS Indication" if required, and marks the subscriber record "Check Not Required" after completion.

column1: What actions does the HLR/HSS perform after restarting due to a failure?
column2: After a restart, the HLR/HSS reloads all data from non-volatile backup, resets "MS Purged" flags, and sends reset messages to VLRs, SGSNs, MMEs, ProSe Function, and V2X Control Function.
column3: The technical overview revolves around the Home Location Register/Home Subscriber Server (HLR/HSS) in a telecommunications network. The HLR/HSS serves as a central database storing subscriber information and supporting call processing functions. In the event of HLR/HSS failures, restoration procedures are activated to ensure continuity. Mobile-terminated call processing, location updating, and management of subscriber data are critical functions explained. The consequences of subscriber data loss or corruption are addressed, along with actions during HLR/HSS restarts and call handling during restoration processes. Additionally, there's a mention of GPRS Gateway Support Node (GGSN) failure and the restoration of data, specifically concerning PDP contexts and MBMS.

column1: How does the VLR handle a mobile-terminated call during the restoration process?
column2: The VLR, upon receiving a "Process Access Request" after successful authentication, checks the "Location Information Confirmed in HLR" indicator. If not confirmed, it triggers an "Update Location" to the HLR.

column1: What procedures does the SGSN follow upon receiving an HLR/HSS reset?
column2: Upon HLR/HSS reset, the SGSN marks relevant MM contexts as invalid, sets the NGAF (Non-GPRS Alert Flag) if needed, and performs update location procedures towards the HLR/HSS.

column1: How does the MME handle UE activity after an HSS reset?
column2: After detecting activity from a marked UE or other triggers, the MME marks relevant MM contexts as invalid, sets NEAF (Non-EPS Alert Flag) if needed, and performs update location procedures towards the HSS.

column1: What is the purpose of periodic location updating for an MS?
column2: Periodic location updating reduces the time to confirm an MS's location after location register failure. It requires the MS to establish radio contact at intervals to confirm its location.

column1: In a GPRS-attached MS, when are periodic RA updates performed?
column2: GPRS-attached MSs perform periodic RA updates. If the Gs interface is installed, RA updates are performed, and periodic LA updates are not performed. The procedure depends on Gs interface installation.

column1: How are authentication triplets reused in a 3G authentication regime in the VLR?
column2: In a 3G authentication regime, quintuplets in a 3G VLR shall not be reused when no unused authentication quintuplets are available for an IMSI record.

column1: What happens when the GGSN detects a restart in the GGSN with activated PDP contexts?
column2: After detecting a GGSN restart, the GGSN deactivates all affected PDP contexts and requests the MS to reactivate them.

column1: What actions does the GGSN take during mobile terminated transmission after a GGSN restart?
column2: During mobile-terminated transmission after restart, the GGSN discards the received PDU for which no PDP context exists and may return a GTP error indication to the originating node.

column1: How does the SGSN handle data or signaling received for an MS with no MM context after an SGSN restart?
column2: If data or signaling is received for an MS with no MM context after an SGSN restart, the SGSN discards the data or signaling.

column1: What is the impact of the loss or corruption of subscriber data in the HLR/HSS?
column2: The loss or corruption of subscriber data in the HLR/HSS affects not only the HLR/HSS's own PLMN but also the service for its mobiles in other PLMNs.

column1: What actions are performed when an HLR/HSS restarts after a failure?
column2: When an HLR/HSS restarts after a failure, it reloads all data from the non-volatile backup, resets "MS Purged" flags, marks each subscriber record as "SS Check Required," and sends reset messages to VLRs, SGSNs, and MMEs.

column1: How is mobile-terminated call processing handled during restoration procedures?
column2: If the VLR receives a "Process Access Request" indicating "Location Information Not Confirmed in HLR," it triggers an "Update Location" to the HLR, and upon success, it proceeds with call processing.

column1: What happens during periodic location updating for an MS?
column2: The time taken to confirm the location of an MS after location register failure is governed by the frequency of radio contact. The MS may establish radio contact at intervals to confirm its location.

column1: Describe the procedures for restoration of data in the GGSN after a failure.
column2: When a GGSN fails, affected PDP contexts become invalid. After GGSN restart, PDP contexts, MBMS UE contexts, and MBMS Bearer contexts stored in the GGSN become invalid and may be deleted.

column1: What actions does an SMLC perform when it restarts after a failure in the context of data restoration for associated LMUs?
column2: When an SMLC restarts after a failure, it reloads all administered LMU data from non-volatile back-up, reinitializes temporary data for each LMU, and performs data restoration for affected Type A and Type B LMUs by opening a signaling connection and sending an LLP Reset message to the LMU.
column3: The provided text describes various procedures related to the restoration of data in different components of a GSM network, such as SMLC, LMU, MME, SGW, PGW, VLR, and more. The procedures cover scenarios like restarts, failures, and partial failures, detailing specific actions taken by each component. Some key aspects include reloading data, reinitializing temporary data, performing data restoration for LMUs, handling restarts in MME and SGW, supporting MBMS bearer services, managing partial failures, and updating location information during various network events. The text emphasizes the importance of maintaining reliable connections and ensuring proper restoration of services in different network elements.

column1: How does an SMLC restore data for a specific LMU in the context of GSM?
column2: An SMLC may restore data for a specific LMU when the data is considered unreliable (e.g., due to lack of communication or inconsistent messages). It opens a signaling connection to the LMU (if Type A) and sends an LLP Reset message. The LMU cancels any ongoing tasks and returns an LLP Reset acknowledgment to the SMLC.

column1: What actions does an LMU take when it restarts following a failure in the GSM network?
column2: After an LMU restarts following a failure, it reinitializes all data related to LCS measurement and O&M tasks, performs an "IMSI Attach" for Type A LMU, opens a signaling connection to its controlling SMLC, and sends an LLP Status Update message indicating the restart. The SMLC updates its data regarding the LMU's state and returns an LLP Update Status acknowledgment.

column1: Describe the procedures for restoring data in the MME after a restart.
column2: After an MME restart, it deletes all MM Bearer contexts affected by the restart. The MBMS GW, upon detecting the restart, re-establishes active MBMS bearer services by initiating MBMS Session Start procedures. The restart procedures include updating session parameters and ensuring the MBMS GW does not delete the MBMS Bearer context unless necessary conditions are met. Optional network-triggered service restoration and handling Downlink Data Notification messages are also specified.

column1: How does the MME handle Mobile Originated Tracking Area Updating or E-UTRAN Attach during a restart?
column2: For attach, if the UE is unknown in the MME, it creates an MM context and performs an "Update Location" to confirm subscriber and location information. The MME may also update VCSG location for CSG/hybrid cells. For tracking area update, if the UE is unknown, the MME rejects the TA update, and the UE needs to perform a new attach. The MME updates subscriber and location information during these procedures.

column1: Explain the procedures for Mobile Terminated NIDD procedure during MME restart.
column2: During Mobile Terminated NIDD procedure, if the SCEF receives a MT-Data-Answer with a failure cause that UE cannot be found, the SCEF deletes all bearer contexts of this UE and may notify the Operation and Maintenance network element. If a subsequent NIDD Submit request is received for the deleted bearer, the SCEF follows the specified procedure.

column1: What actions does the MME take during the restart of a peer node, specifically SGW failure?
column2: When an MME detects a peer SGW failure, it may either delete all PDN connection table data associated with the failed peer or follow procedures specified in clause 27 to restore the affected PDN connections. The MME has the option to clear external resources or perform advanced forms of restoration based on implementation.

column1: How does the MME handle partial failure and associated procedures during PDN Connection Establishment?
column2: If the MME supports partial failure handling, during PDN connection establishment, it provides one MME FQ-CSID containing exactly one CSID for that PDN connection to the SGW. The MME stores Node-ID and CSID values from the FQ-CSID provided by the SGW and PGW in its PDN Connection table. The MME ensures previously used FQ-CSIDs are not immediately reused after a partial/full failure.

column1: What procedures does the MME follow during its partial failure, including actions towards the SGW peers?
column2: When an MME detects partial failure, it may perform implementation-specific operations to clean up residual state associated with CSIDs. The MME sends a GTPv2 Delete PDN Connection Set Request to SGW peers containing MME CSIDs of the failing component(s). Upon receiving a successful response, the MME concludes that the SGW peer has initiated internal deletion of corresponding PDN connections.

column1: Explain the procedures during a peer's partial failure and the MME's response to a Delete PDN Connection Set Request from an SGW.
column2: If the MME supports partial failure handling, upon receiving a Delete PDN Connection Set Request from an SGW, the MME retrieves all PDN connections corresponding to the FQ-CSIDs present in the message and deletes them. The MME sends a Delete PDN Connection Set Response with an appropriate Cause value to the SGW.

column1: What are the general considerations and procedures for handling partial failure at the MME?
column2: General considerations and procedures for handling partial failure at the MME are specified in Clause 23. During PDN Connection Establishment, the MME provides an FQ-CSID to the SGW, ensuring unique FQ-CSIDs after a partial/full failure. The MME supports partial failure handling by verifying CSID(s) presence during its partial failure and sending a GTPv2 Delete PDN Connection Set Request to SGW peers.

column1: What specific actions does the MME take during MME Partial Failure in relation to CSIDs?
column2: During MME Partial Failure, the MME may perform implementation-specific operations to clean up residual state associated with CSIDs. It sends a GTPv2 Delete PDN Connection Set Request containing MME CSIDs to SGW peers. The MME concludes SGW peer initiation of internal deletion upon receiving a successful response.

column1: Describe the procedures during PDN Connection Removal or Modification, especially in the context of MME and SGW support for partial failure handling.
column2: During PDN Connection Removal or Modification, if the MME and SGW support partial failure handling, various actions are taken, including clearing stored FQ-CSID values, including FQ-CSIDs in relevant S11 messages, and deleting PDN data and associated FQ-CSID values. MME FQ-CSID presence in S11 responses indicates SGW support for partial failure handling.

column1: How does the MME handle Mobile Originated Service Request during restart, particularly when the UE is unknown?
column2: For Mobile Originated Service Request, if the UE is unknown in the MME, the MME rejects the service request with an appropriate cause. To remain attached, the UE needs to perform a new attach and (re)activate its EPS Bearer contexts. If the MME has an MM context for the UE with certain indicators not confirmed, it may perform an "Update VCSG Location" to the CSS for CSG/hybrid cells.

column1: What procedures does the MME follow in case of a peer UCMF failure, considering URCMP-based restart procedures?
column2: When an MME detects a peer UCMF failure with or without restart, it considers the mapping information received from the failed UCMF deprecated. The subscription to get notifications from the UCMF becomes invalid. The MME may retrieve such mapping information upon subsequent UE-AMF signaling during registration procedures.

column1: How does the MME handle SGW and PGW FQ-CSID values during PDN Connection Removal or Modification?
column2: During PDN Connection Removal or Modification, the MME handles SGW and PGW FQ-CSID values by overwriting current stored values with received values over S11 messages. The MME ensures proper handling of FQ-CSID values for both MME and SGW during these procedures.

column1: What happens when a BSS (Base Station Subsystem) fails in A/Gb mode according to the given context?
column2: When a BSS fails in A/Gb mode, all its BSS contexts affected by the failure become invalid and are deleted. The BSS storage of data is volatile.
column3: The generated pairs of questions and answers provide detailed information about the Mobility Management Entity (MME) and Multimedia Broadcast/Multicast Service (MBMS) in the context of LTE (Long-Term Evolution) networks. The topics covered include MME handling of MBMS bearer services, establishment and modification of MBMS Service Areas through the MCE Configuration Update procedure, re-establishment of MBMS bearer services after MCE failure, handling of MBMS Session Start Requests with past absolute start times, MME actions upon detecting M3AP path failures, and MCE handling of MBMS Session Start Requests for ongoing sessions with the same Temporary Mobile Group Identity (TMGI). These details encompass various aspects of LTE network protocols, procedures, and interactions between network elements to ensure efficient and robust delivery of MBMS services.

column1: How does an SGSN handle the unavailability of an RNC/BSC or a Reset from an RNC/BSC in Iu mode?
column2: In the event of an RNC/BSC failure in Iu mode, an SGSN recognizing the unavailability or receiving a Reset from an RNC/BSC locally releases the Radio Access Bearers (RABs) for all affected Packet Data Protocol (PDP) contexts. Recovery of affected PDP contexts using Direct Tunnel occurs when the SGSN receives an Iu connection establishment request from the mobile station or when the GGSN informs the SGSN of a GTP error indication from the RNC.

column1: What does the RNC do to avoid inconsistent TEID allocation throughout the network after an RNC restart?
column2: The RNC ensures, as far as possible, that previously used TEID (Tunnel Endpoint Identifier) values are not immediately reused after an RNC restart. This is done to prevent inconsistent TEID allocation throughout the network.

column1: How does the S4-SGSN handle the failure of an RNC/BSC in Iu mode when using S4?
column2: In case of an RNC/BSC failure in Iu mode using S4, the S4-SGSN initiates the release of access bearers for all bearers towards the Serving Gateway (Serving GW) as defined in 3GPP TS 23.060. Additionally, the S4-SGSN may send the Release Access Bearers Request message to the Serving GW based on operator policy. Any affected EPS (Evolved Packet System) bearers contexts in the Serving GW are recovered when the SGSN receives an Iu connection establishment request from the mobile station or when the Serving GW initiates the Network Triggered Service Request procedure.

column1: What actions should the MME take in the case of an eNodeB failure in E-UTRAN?
column2: In the case of an eNodeB failure in E-UTRAN, the MME shall locally delete the eNodeB-related information and initiate the release of all S1 bearers towards the Serving Gateway (Serving GW). The MME may defer the deactivation of GBR bearers for a short period to allow re-establishment of radio and S1 bearers. If the Serving GW receives a Release Access Bearers Request message, it releases all eNodeB-related information but retains other elements of the UE's Serving GW context. Any bearer contexts affected by eNodeB failure without a valid S1-U tunnel in the Serving GW are recovered during the UE Triggered Service Request or Network Triggered Service Request procedure.

column1: How does the MME handle UE context retention in the case of an eNodeB failure in E-UTRAN?
column2: The MME, which does not support UE context retention at SCTP recovery and recognizes unavailability of an eNodeB, locally deletes the eNodeB-related information. It initiates the release of all S1 bearers towards the Serving GW. If the MME supports UE context retention at SCTP recovery, it keeps UEs in ECM-CONNECTED and suspends UE context data for UEs in ECM-IDLE that used the S1 signaling connection before it was broken. Upon subsequent S1 Setup, the MME and eNodeB may agree to retain existing UE-related contexts and related signaling connections.

column1: What should an (H)eNodeB do after restarting regarding warning message data in E-UTRAN?
column2: After restarting, an (H)eNodeB shall delete all its warning message data. If the warning message service is operational, the (H)eNodeB sends a PWS Restart Indication message to the CBC, including identity information. The CBC considers the warning message service restarted in the reported cell(s) and re-sends the warning message data to the (H)eNodeB for these cells.

column1: How does an eNodeB handle warning message broadcasting during an S1-AP path failure?
column2: During an S1-AP path failure, the eNodeB continues to broadcast warning messages. Upon recovery of the S1-AP path, the eNodeB proceeds as if no S1-AP path failure had occurred. The eNodeB and CBC/MME support procedures like Write-Replace-Warning-Indication and Stop-Warning-Indication to keep the warning message data synchronized in case of desynchronization during the path failure.

column1: What actions should the MCE take upon failure, and recovery in the context of MBMS services in E-UTRAN?
column2: Upon MCE failure, the MCE releases all MBMS services locally and towards E-UTRAN. If the MME recognizes MCE unavailability or receives a Reset or M3 Setup Request message from an MCE, it maintains related MBMS bearer contexts but locally deletes MCE-related information. Upon recovery, the MCE initiates a Reset or M3 Setup Request procedure towards the related MME. The MME subsequently re-establishes affected MBMS bearer services through MBMS Session Start procedures.

column1: How does the MCE handle an MBMS Session Start Request for an ongoing session with the same TMGI?
column2: The MCE accepts an MBMS Session Start Request for an ongoing MBMS session with the same TMGI:

column1: How does the MME handle the establishment of MBMS bearer services in an MCE during the modification of MBMS Service Areas via the MCE Configuration Update procedure?
column2: When establishing MBMS bearer services in an MCE and modifying MBMS Service Areas through the MCE Configuration Update procedure, the MME encodes the MBMS Session Start Request as specified in clause 15A.3 upon receiving a Reset or M3 Setup Request message from the MCE.

column1: What steps does the MME take when re-establishing MBMS bearer services affected by MCE failure?
column2: Upon receipt of a Reset or M3 Setup Request message from the MCE indicating MCE failure, the MME subsequently re-establishes the MBMS bearer services affected by initiating MBMS Session Start procedures towards the MCE. The contents of the MBMS Session Start Request are encoded with the same parameters as in the original request, with specific exceptions related to re-establishment flags, start time adjustments, and estimated session duration.

column1: How does the MCE handle MBMS Session Start Requests with an absolute start time in the past?
column2: The MCE is capable of accepting MBMS Session Start Requests with an absolute start time parameter in the past. This allows flexibility in handling requests that may have been delayed due to network conditions or other factors.

column1: What actions does the MME take upon detecting an M3AP path failure in the context of MBMS services?
column2: Upon detection of an M3AP path failure, the MCE releases all MBMS services affected by the failure either immediately or after a pre-configured time period if corresponding MBMS bearer contexts are not re-established via any MME. The MME maintains related MBMS bearer contexts but locally deletes MCE-related information. Upon recovery of the M3AP path, the MCE initiates a Reset or M3 Setup Request procedure towards the related MME, and the MME subsequently re-establishes affected MBMS bearer services through MBMS Session Start procedures.

column1: How does the MCE handle MBMS Session Start Requests for an ongoing session with the same TMGI?
column2: The MCE accepts an MBMS Session Start Request for an ongoing MBMS session with the same TMGI:From the same or a different MME than the current MME controlling the session, if the message includes the "MBMS session re-establishment indication" flag.From the MME currently controlling the session, if the MCE supports maintaining MBMS bearer contexts during a pre-configured time period after an M3AP path failure, MME restart, or MCE failure, and the message is received during that period without the "MBMS session re-establishment indication" flag.

column1: What happens when a SGW fails, and how are the Bearer contexts affected?
column2: When a SGW fails, all its Bearer contexts affected by the failure become invalid and may be deleted. SGW storage of subscriber data is volatile.
column3: The provided context outlines procedures related to the restoration of data in the SGW (Serving Gateway) within the LTE/4G mobile network architecture. When the SGW experiences a failure, such as in the case of SGW-C, SGW-U, or peer nodes like MME (Mobility Management Entity) and PGW (Packet Data Network Gateway), various restoration procedures are described. These include actions to be taken after the restart of different SGW components, deletion of bearer contexts affected by restarts, and coordination with peer nodes for restoration. The document emphasizes the importance of preventing immediate reuse of certain values after restarts to avoid inconsistencies. Additionally, partial failure handling at the SGW is discussed, covering scenarios such as PDN connection establishment, removal, or modification, with a focus on communication and coordination with MME and PGW. The support for partial failure handling is conditional based on the presence of specific identifiers (FQ-CSID) in messages exchanged between network elements.

column1: What action does the SGW take upon receiving a GTP U PDU for which no Bearer context exists?
column2: What action does the SGW take upon receiving a GTP U PDU for which no Bearer context exists?When the SGW receives a GTP U PDU for which no Bearer context exists, it shall discard the GTP U PDU and return a GTP error indication to the originating node or follow specified procedures if PDN connection restoration is supported.

column1: How does the SGW handle TEID values after an SGW restart, and why?
column2: The SGW should ensure that previously used TEID values are not immediately reused after an SGW restart to avoid inconsistent TEID allocation throughout the network.

column1: What actions does the SGW take during Restoration Procedures after an SGW restart?
column2: After an SGW restart, the SGW shall delete all MM Bearer contexts affected by the restart and place local SGW restart counter value in GTPv2 Echo requests/responses messages and PMIPv6 heartbeat responses.

column1: What is the procedure for handling a SGW-C failure, and how does it avoid inconsistent TEID allocation?
column2: In case of SGW-C failure, all its Bearer and Session contexts are affected and may be deleted. The SGW-C ensures previously used F-TEID values are not immediately reused after a restart to avoid inconsistent TEID allocation throughout the network.

column1: What information does the SGW-C include during an SGW-C Restart in Heartbeat Request/Response and Sx Association Setup Request/Response Messages?
column2: During an SGW-C Restart, the SGW-C includes a local SGW-C Recovery Time Stamp value in all Heartbeat Request/Response and Sx Association Setup Request/Response Messages.

column1: How does the SGW-U ensure the restoration of Sx sessions after an SGW-U failure?
column2: If F-TEID allocation is performed in the SGW-U, it ensures that previously used F-TEID values are not immediately reused after a SGW-U restart to avoid inconsistent TEID allocation. The restoration procedure includes placing local SGW-U Recovery Time Stamp value in Heartbeat Request/Response and Sx Association Setup Request/Response Messages.

column1: What actions does the SGW-C take upon detecting a peer PFCP entity restart in the SGW-U?
column2: The SGW-C in SGW-U receives the recovery time stamps of the PFCP entity(ies) and deletes all Sx session contexts affected by the restart. It discards GTP U PDU not matching any PDRs and returns a GTP error indication.

column1: How does the SGW handle partial failures, specifically during PDN Connection Establishment?
column2: During PDN Connection Establishment, if the SGW supports the feature, it provides SGW FQ-CSID to the PGW and MME and forwards MME FQ-CSID to the PGW. The SGW stores Node-ID and CSID values from FQ-CSID and determines MME and PGW support for partial failure handling.

column1: What procedures does the SGW follow during a partial failure affecting SGW itself?
column2: During an SGW partial failure, the SGW verifies corresponding CSID(s), performs implementation-specific cleanup operations, and sends GTPv2 Delete PDN Connection Set Request messages to supporting MME and PGW peers.

column1: How does the SGW handle PDN Connection Removal or Modification when partial failure handling is supported?
column2: During PDN Connection Removal or Modification, the SGW includes SGW FQ-CSID in relevant messages, informs feature-supporting PGW about FQ-CSID changes, and may send messages to the MME if partial failure handling is supported.

column1: How does the SGW respond to a peer's partial failure, specifically when receiving a S11 GTPv2 Delete PDN Connection Set Request from an MME?
column2: The SGW retrieves PDN connections corresponding to FQ-CSID(s) provided by the MME, sends S5/S8 GTPv2 Delete PDN Connection Set Request to supporting PGW, deletes retrieved PDN connections, and sends a S11 GTPv2 Delete PDN Connection Set Response to the MME.

column1: What actions does the SGW take during PDN Connection Removal or Modification when the MME is being relocated?
column2: During PDN Connection Removal or Modification, if the MME is being relocated, the SGW clears the currently stored MME FQ-CSID value.

column1: How does the SGW handle the detection of full/complete failure of an MME or PGW?
column2: If the SGW detects the full/complete failure of an MME or PGW, it may send a Delete PDN Connection Set Request message containing FQ-CSIDs of associated hanging PDN connections to the corresponding remote node.

column1: What happens to Bearer contexts when a PGW fails?
column2: When a PGW fails, all its Bearer contexts affected by the failure become invalid and may be deleted.
column3: The text details protocols and procedures for managing failures and restarts across various elements in a telecommunications network, including PGW, ePDG, TWAN, BM-SC, GCS AS, and UCMF. It highlights key aspects like partial failure handling at PGW during PDN connection establishment, detection of partial failure, and restoration processes. Additionally, it covers the restoration of data in MBMS GW, addressing restart scenarios and communication with BM-SC. For ePDG, the text outlines restart procedures, failure handling, and restoration efforts following PGW or PGW-U restart. TWAN procedures include restart protocols, failure handling, and actions after detecting PGW or PGW-U restart. The document emphasizes specific actions for each network element during failures, such as cleanup, verification, and communication with affected components.

column1: What action should the PGW take upon receiving a GTP U PDU for which no Bearer context exists?
column2: The PGW shall discard the GTP U PDU and return a GTP error indication to the originating node (SGW/ePDG/TWAN).

column1: What does the PGW do to avoid inconsistent TEID allocation after a restart?
column2: The PGW should ensure, as far as possible, that previously used TEID values are not immediately reused after a restart to avoid inconsistent TEID allocation throughout the network.

column1: What are the restoration procedures after a PGW restart?
column2: After a PGW restart, the PGW shall delete all MM Bearer contexts affected by the restart. It shall also place the PGW restart counter value in all GTPv2 echo requests/responses and PMIPv6 heartbeat responses.

column1: How does the PGW handle the restart of the PGW-C?
column2: When a PGW-C fails, all its Bearer, session contexts, and Sx associations affected by the failure become invalid. The PGW-C should ensure that previously used F-TEID values are not immediately reused after a restart.

column1: What should the PGW-C do after a restart?
column2: After a PGW-C restart, it shall delete all MM Bearer and session contexts and Sx associations affected by the restart. The PGW-C shall place the local PGW-C Recovery Time Stamp value in all Heartbeat Request/Response and Sx Association Setup Request/Response Messages.

column1: How does the PGW-U handle a failure?
column2: When a PGW-U fails, all its Session contexts and Sx associations affected by the failure become invalid. The PGW-U ensures that previously used F-TEID values are not immediately reused after a restart.

column1: What actions are taken during or after a PGW-U restart?
column2: During or immediately after a PGW-U restart, the PGW-U shall place the local PGW-U Recovery Time Stamp value in all Heartbeat Request/Response and Sx Association Setup Request/Response Messages.

column1: Can a restarted PGW-U determine the CP function responsible for an incoming packet?
column2: In some cases, a restarted PGW-U cannot determine the CP function responsible for an incoming packet, for example, when a UP function is controlled by multiple CP functions for the same APN.

column1: What happens when the PGW detects a peer SGW/ePDG/TWAN failure?
column2: The PGW deletes all PDN connection table data/MM bearer contexts associated with the peer node that fails and frees any internal PGW resources.

column1: What is the consequence of a peer PGW restarting in the TWAN network?
column2: When a peer PGW restarts in the TWAN network, the TWAN shall delete all PDN connection table data and bearer contexts associated with the failing peer node.

column1: How does the TWAN determine if a peer PGW supports partial failure handling during PDN connection establishment?
column2: The TWAN determines that the PGW supports partial failure handling by checking the presence of the PGW FQ-CSID in the Create Session Response for GTPv2 based S2a and/or Proxy Binding Acknowledgement message for PMIPv6 based S2a.

column1: What actions does the TWAN take during a partial failure if it detects that one or more CSIDs are present for the component undergoing a fault?
column2: If the TWAN detects one or more CSIDs for a component undergoing a partial fault, it may perform implementation-specific operations to clean up residual state associated with the CSID(s) and send a Delete PDN Connection Set Request to PGW peers supporting the feature.

column1: How does the BM-SC handle the restart of a GCS AS in deployments without a Diameter Agent?
column2: In deployments without a Diameter Agent, the BM-SC detects the restart of a GCS AS using either the Diameter Origin-State-Id AVP or the Diameter Restart-Counter AVP. It deallocates TMGIs assigned to the restarted GCS AS and stops related MBMS bearers to free resources in E-UTRAN.

column1: What occurs after a GCS AS restart in terms of MBMS bearer contexts and TMGIs?
column2: After a GCS AS restart, the GCS AS loses its MBMS bearer contexts and knowledge of the TMGIs allocated by the BM-SC. The BM-SC assumes that all TMGIs assigned by the restarted GCS AS have been de-allocated, and related MBMS bearers have been deactivated.

column1: How does the UCMF handle a restart scenario?
column2: The UCMF, assumed as a front-end application function with a persistent database, may restart. However, it retains dictionary mapping information between UE Radio Capability and UE Radio Capability IDs. It does not update its Recovery Time Stamp in this case.

column1: What action does the UCMF take when detecting a peer MME failure with or without restart?
column2: When the UCMF detects a peer MME failure (with or without restart), it deletes the subscription created by the failed MME.

column1: What are the entities involved in GTP-C based restart procedures?
column2: The entities involved in GTP-C based restart procedures include SGSN, GGSN, MME, SGW, PGW, TWAN, ePDG, and HRPD Access Node.
column3: The provided technical documentation outlines restart procedures for various communication entities, such as GTP-C, GTP-U, PMIPv6, PFCP, and URCMP, across different interfaces in mobile networks. Specifically, GTP-C entities utilize Echo Request and Response messages or GTP-C messages with Recovery Information Elements for restart detection, maintaining local and remote Restart counters. GTP-U entities, when supporting restart, use Echo Request, Echo Response, and Error Indication messages with Recovery Time Stamp Information Elements. PMIPv6 entities utilize a Heartbeat mechanism, while PFCP and URCMP entities employ Heartbeat Request and Response messages for restart detection, including Recovery Time Stamp Information Elements. The documentation delves into the intricacies of each procedure, emphasizing counter maintenance, timestamp comparison, and error handling based on operators' policies. It also addresses scenarios involving NAT devices. The outlined procedures are crucial for ensuring the reliability and continuity of communication in mobile networks.

column1: How does a GTP-C entity detect and handle a restart?
column2: A GTP-C entity detects and handles a restart by utilizing GTPv1-C or GTPv2-C Echo Request and Echo Response messages or GTP-C messages containing the Recovery Information Element.

column1: How many Restart counters does a GTP-C entity maintain?
column2: A GTP-C entity maintains two Restart counters: a remote Restart counter of a peer in volatile memory and an own, or local Restart counter in non-volatile memory.

column1: What action does a GTP-C entity take after restarting?
column2: After restarting, a GTP-C entity immediately increments all local Restart counters and clears all remote Restart counters.

column1: How does a GTP-C entity probe the liveliness of each peer?
column2: A GTP-C entity may probe the liveliness of each peer by sending an Echo Request message.

column1: What is the significance of the Restart counter in GTP-C messages?
column2: The Restart counter in GTP-C messages is associated with the GTP-C entity identified by the sender's F-TEID or SGSN/GGSN IP address for control plane.

column1: How does a GTP-C entity handle a possible race condition during restart?
column2: If a race condition is detected (newer message arriving before the older one), the received new Restart counter value shall be discarded, and an error may be logged.

column1: According to the operator's policy, how can a GTP-C entity verify if a peer has really restarted?
column2: The GTP-C entity may verify if a peer has really restarted by sending one or more Echo Request messages and determining restart based on the received Restart counter values.

column1: What is the optional feature for GTP-U based restart procedures?
column2: The support of GTP-U based restart procedure is optional for a GTP-U entity.

column1: What messages does a GTP-U entity utilize for restart detection?
column2: A GTP-U entity utilizes GTP-U Echo Request, Echo Response messages, and GTP-U Error Indication message containing the Recovery Time Stamp Information Element for restart detection.

column1: What is the purpose of the Echo Request / Response procedure in GTP-based interfaces?
column2: The Echo Request / Response procedure in GTP-based interfaces is used for probing the liveliness of each peer. For GTPv1-C, it involves periodic sending of Echo Request messages, and for GTPv2, Echo Request messages are sent to detect the liveliness of the peer.
column3: The text describes path management procedures for GTP-C based, PMIP, and PFCP interfaces in a telecommunication network. For GTP-based interfaces, it recommends using Echo Request/Response, providing specific guidelines for GTPv1-C and GTPv2 versions. PMIP interfaces utilize Heartbeat Request/Response for SGW and PGW detection, while PFCP interfaces employ a similar Heartbeat mechanism. URCMP interfaces detect peer unavailability through Heartbeat Request/Response. Signaling path failure detection involves counters and timers, and upon detection, network nodes may delete or maintain connections based on operator configuration. Specific requirements are outlined for SGW, MBMS GW, MME, and SGSN functionalities, covering S11/S4, S5, Sm, Sn, and SGmb interfaces. Procedures for restoring services and handling MBMS sessions during path failures are detailed, addressing transient and non-transient failures and providing considerations for maintaining connections during transient failures. The document emphasizes minimizing unnecessary signaling and highlights the importance of timely restoration in a fine-tuning question-answering dataset context.

column1: How often can a GTPv2 entity send an Echo Request message in the path management procedures?
column2: The frequency of sending GTPv2 Echo Request messages is implementation-specific, but it should not be more often than every 60 seconds on each path.

column1: What is the recommended condition for sending GTPv2 Echo Request in path management?
column2: It is recommended to send GTPv2 Echo Request only when a GTP-C entity has not received any GTP response message for a previously sent request message on the GTP-C path for an implementation-dependent period.

column1: How does the PMIP-based S5/S8 interface detect peer unavailability in path management procedures?
column2: The PMIP-based S5/S8 interface detects peer unavailability by sending a series of PMIPv6 Heartbeat Request messages and not receiving a PMIPv6 Heartbeat Response message within a specified period, as specified in 3GPP TS 29.275 [16].

column1: What is the procedure for detecting a peer UP function unavailability in PFCP based interfaces?
column2: The CP function in PFCP based Sxa/Sxb/Sxc interfaces detects a peer UP function unavailability by sending a series of PFCP Heartbeat Request messages and not receiving a PFCP Heartbeat Response message within a specified period, as defined in 3GPP TS 29.244 [43].

column1: What may the S4-SGSN do in case of a PGW Downlink Triggering Notification and the S4 path of the related UE is still available?
column2: The S4-SGSN may restore the PDN connection(s) of the UE by performing the S4-SGSN triggered Serving GW relocation procedure as defined in clause 9.2.2.4 of 3GPP TS 23.060.

column1: What procedure should the BM-SC follow upon detecting a non-transient SGmb path failure?
column2: The BM-SC should re-establish the active MBMS bearer services affected by the SGmb path failure by initiating MBMS Session Start procedure(s) towards an alternative MBMS GW (if available) or towards the same MBMS GW once the SGmb path is recovered.

column1: How should the BM-SC handle an SGmb path recovery if it has already moved the control of the MBMS session to an alternative MBMS GW?
column2: The BM-SC should send an MBMS Session Stop Request message to the MBMS GW previously controlling the session with a "Local MBMS bearer context release" indication.

column1: What action should the BM-SC take if the SGmb path failure is transient from its perspective?
column2: If the SGmb path failure is transient from the BM-SC's perspective, it should consider that the MBMS session is still controlled by the related MBMS GW and proceed as if there had been no SGmb path failure.

column1: What mechanisms can the BM-SC use to detect an MB2-C path failure in deployments without a Diameter Agent?
column2: The BM-SC can detect an MB2-C path failure using mechanisms specified in the Diameter Base Protocol (e.g., transport connection failure, GCS AS peer not responding) or the MBMS Heartbeat procedure (see clause 29) if this procedure is supported.

column1: What modifications does the PGW need to make for GTP-based S5 during the PGW triggered SGW restoration procedure?
column2: For GTP-based S5, the PGW shall include the PGW F-TEID for control plane in the PGW Downlink Triggering Notification message during the SGW restoration procedure.

column1: How does the MBMS GW handle a non-transient SGi-mb path failure?
column2: Upon detecting a non-transient SGi-mb path failure, the MBMS GW may tear down the affected MBMS sessions by sending MBMS Session Stop Request message(s) to the MME/SGSN(s) serving the sessions and Session Termination Request message(s) to the BM-SC with a terminating cause signaling a user plane failure.

column1: What is the purpose of maintaining bearer contexts during transient path failures in the user plane?
column2: Maintaining bearer contexts during transient path failures enables the delivery of end-user services upon path re-establishment and avoids unnecessary signaling in the network for restoring those bearers.

column1: How does an MME behave upon receiving a Delete Bearer Request with the cause "S1-U Path Failure" for deleting a PDN connection?
column2: The MME shall deactivate the corresponding PDN connection using the "reactivation requested" cause value as specified in clause 5.10.3 of 3GPP TS 23.401 [15].

column1: What happens when a GGSN receives a GTP error indication for a PDP context with the DTI flag set?
column2: The GGSN marks the associated PDP context as invalid, informs the SGSN about the GTP error indication from RNC, and forwards subsequent downlink packets to the SGSN after re-establishing the tunnel.
column3: In the context of GTP (GPRS Tunnelling Protocol) error indication handling, the document outlines specific procedures for various network elements. When a GTPv1-U Error Indication message is received, network elements such as GGSN, SGSN, RNC, eNodeB, SGW, PGW, MBMS GW, ePDG, TWAN, and MME follow distinct protocols. The handling involves actions like marking PDP contexts as invalid, deleting contexts, initiating RAB Release procedures, sending Deactivate PDP Context Request messages, and notifying Operation and Maintenance network elements. The procedures vary based on the source of the error indication (RNC, SGSN, GGSN, SGW, PGW, MBMS GW, ePDG, TWAN) and the nature of the bearer context (default or specific). For instance, if an eNodeB receives a GTP error indication, it may initiate the E-RAB Release procedure and locally release the E-RAB. Similarly, the SGW, PGW, and other elements have specific actions based on the received GTP error indications, including deleting bearer contexts, notifying Operation and Maintenance, and initiating specific procedures for different network scenarios.

column1: How does the SGSN handle a GTP error indication from a GGSN?
column2: The SGSN deletes its PDP context, may notify the Operation and Maintenance network element, and sends a Deactivate PDP Context Request to the MS with cause "re-activation required."

column1: In the context of MBMS, what actions are taken when an Error Indication is received from an SGSN?
column2: The receiving GGSN deletes information associated with the SGSN in its MBMS Bearer Context, may request re-establishment of the MBMS Bearer Context, and deletes the MBMS Bearer Context if certain conditions are met.

column1: How does the S4-SGSN handle a GTP error indication from an SGW?
column2: The S4-SGSN deletes its Bearer context, may notify the Operation and Maintenance network element, and sends a Deactivate PDP Context Request to the MS with cause "re-activation required."

column1: What actions are taken by the RNC when receiving a GTP error indication from the SGSN or GGSN?
column2: The RNC initiates the RAB Release procedure with the appropriate error cause and locally releases the RAB immediately without waiting for a response from the SGSN or GGSN.

column1: How does the eNodeB handle a GTP error indication from the SGW over an S1-U tunnel?
column2: The eNodeB initiates the E-RAB Release procedure, locally releases the E-RAB immediately, and may send additional messages based on specific conditions.

column1: What is the SGW's response to a GTP error indication for a Bearer Context with the DTI flag set from an RNC?
column2: The SGW does not delete the associated Bearer Context but deletes all RNC GTP-U tunnel TEIDs, sends a Downlink Data Notification to the SGSN, and starts buffering downlink packets.

column1: How does the PGW handle a GTP error indication from an SGW for the default bearer?
column2: The PGW deletes all Bearer contexts associated with the PDN connection, may notify the Operation and Maintenance network element, and may initiate additional actions based on specific conditions.

column1: What actions does the MME take upon receiving a GTP error indication from an SGW?
column2: The MME deletes its Bearer context, may notify the Operation and Maintenance network element, and deactivates the corresponding PDN connection towards the UE with the cause "re-activation required."

column1: How does the MBMS GW handle a GTP Error Indication from an SGSN?
column2: The MBMS GW deletes its Bearer context and may notify the Operation and Maintenance network element.

column1: What is the purpose of the partial failure handling feature in MME, SGW, ePDG, TWAN, and PGW?
column2: The partial failure handling feature is used to address hardware or software failures that impact a significant number of PDN connections while leaving others unaffected.
column3: The provided text describes the General Partial Failure Handling Procedures for various network elements, including MME, SGW, ePDG, TWAN, and PGW. Partial failure handling is an optional feature, and it is applicable when hardware or software failures impact a significant number of PDN connections. The goal is to clean up hanging PDN connections associated with the failed node. The procedures involve the use of PDN Connection Set Identifiers (CSID) to identify sets of PDN connections within a node, with Fully Qualified CSID (FQ-CSID) combining node identity and CSID for global identification. Nodes supporting the feature exchange FQ-CSIDs during connection establishment and maintain them for partial failure handling. The text outlines rules for handling FQ-CSIDs, including message exchange between nodes, identification of peer support, and actions during session management procedures. Additionally, it covers scenarios for split SGW and PGW, detailing procedures for Sx Session Establishment and modification in case of partial failure. Figures are provided to illustrate FQ-CSID establishment during different procedures.

column1: How is a PDN Connection Set Identifier (CSID) used in partial fault handling?
column2: A PDN CSID identifies a set of PDN connections within a node and is used to inform peer nodes about affected PDN connections for recovery during partial failure. It is an opaque parameter local to a node.

column1: What is the significance of the Fully Qualified CSID (FQ-CSID) in partial failure handling?
column2: The FQ-CSID, comprising the node identity and CSID, globally identifies a set of PDN connections. It is used to match PDN connections during partial failure handling, preventing the accidental removal of unrelated PDN connections.

column1: How does a node supporting partial failure handling determine if a peer node also supports the feature?
column2: If a node receives a peer node's FQ-CSID during specified procedures, it concludes that the peer supports the feature. If no FQ-CSID is received, it concludes that the peer node does not support the feature.

column1: What actions should a node take if it supports partial failure handling and does not receive the peer's FQ-CSID during specified procedures?
column2: If a node does not receive the peer's FQ-CSID, it concludes that the peer does not support the feature and refrains from sending any FQ-CSID IE or partial failure handling specific messages to the peer.

column1: How does the SGW handle FQ-CSID in the context of split SGW and PGW during partial failure handling?
column2: If the SGW supports partial failure handling, it forwards the peer node's FQ-CSID, along with Delete Connection Set Request/Response messages. If a full failure is detected, it may send a Delete PDN Connection Set Request with FQ-CSIDs of hanging PDN connections to the corresponding remote node.

column1: What is the role of FQ-CSID in the Sx Session Establishment procedure for 3GPP access with a split SGW?
column2: In the Sx Session Establishment procedure, if an SGW-C supports partial failure handling, it sends its own FQ-CSID and MME FQ-CSID to the SGW-U. If SGW-U supports the feature, it stores SGW-C FQ-CSID and MME FQ-CSID and sends its own FQ-CSID back to the SGW-C.

column1: How is FQ-CSID established during the Attach or PDN establishment procedure for untrusted non-3GPP access?
column2: If an ePDG/TWAN supports partial failure handling, it sends its FQ-CSID to PGW. If PGW supports the feature, it stores ePDG's/TWAN's FQ-CSID and sends its own FQ-CSID back to ePDG/TWAN.

column1: What is the purpose of the FQ-CSID establishment during the Sx Session Establishment procedure for split PGW?
column2: In the Sx Session Establishment procedure with split PGW, if a PGW-C supports partial failure handling, it sends its own FQ-CSID, along with other FQ-CSIDs, to PGW-U. If PGW-U supports the feature, it stores received FQ-CSIDs and sends its own FQ-CSID back to PGW-C.

column1: How does a node indicate support for partial failure handling during session management procedures?
column2: During session management procedures, a node supporting the feature may update its FQ-CSID to supporting peer nodes in Create Bearer Request/Response, Delete Bearer Request/Response, or Update Bearer Request/Response messages.

column1: What happens when a PCRF fails in the context of PCRF storage of PCC contexts?
column2: When a PCRF fails, the PCC contexts and Diameter sessions affected by the failure are lost in the PCRF. Any non-initial message for which no Diameter session exists will be discarded by the PCRF, and a Diameter error indication is sent to the originating PCRF client.
column3: The provided text outlines procedures related to the restoration of data in the Policy and Charging Rules Function (PCRF) and network-triggered service restoration in a telecommunication network. In the context of PCRF, it describes the consequences of PCRF failure, including the loss of Policy and Charging Control (PCC) contexts and Diameter sessions, and the handling of non-initial messages. The subsequent sections detail the network-triggered service restoration procedures, differentiating between scenarios with and without Idle mode Signalling Reduction (ISR). The process involves maintaining specific bearers and initiating restoration based on operator policies. For scenarios without ISR, the text defines SGW (Serving Gateway) procedures, including the handling of Downlink Data Notification messages and optional actions upon releasing maintained bearers. In the presence of ISR, additional procedures involve SGW maintaining data for both non-failed and restarted nodes, timer management, and communication with the MME (Mobility Management Entity) or S4-SGSN (Serving GPRS Support Node). The text also outlines actions in the MME/SGSN (Mobility Management Entity/Serving GPRS Support Node) and considerations for service restoration with ISR, including the deactivation of ISR during Tracking Area Update (TAU) or Routing Area Update (RAU) procedures. These procedures ensure the network's resilience and the restoration of services in the event of failures.

column1: What is the purpose of the network triggered service restoration procedure, and which network elements support it?
column2: The network triggered service restoration procedure is an optional feature for MME, S4-SGSN, and SGW. It is designed to restore services affected by node failures. The procedure is supported by nodes that support Idle mode Signalling Reduction (ISR).

column1: Under what conditions does the SGW maintain the PDN connection table data and MM bearer contexts for specific S5/S8 bearer contexts in the network triggered service restoration procedure without ISR?
column2: In the absence of ISR, if the SGW detects that an MME or S4-SGSN has restarted, it maintains PDN connection table data and MM bearer contexts for specific S5/S8 bearer contexts eligible for network-initiated service restoration. The SGW initiates the deletion of resources associated with other S5/S8 bearers.

column1: How does the SGW determine S5/S8 bearers eligible for network-initiated service restoration in the absence of ISR?
column2: The eligibility of S5/S8 bearers for network-initiated service restoration is determined by the SGW based on the operator's policy, considering factors such as QCI, ARP, APN, and, if set, the Delay Tolerant Connection Indication (DTCI).

column1: What actions does the SGW take upon receipt of the first downlink user plane or control plane packet on a maintained S5/S8 bearer in the network triggered service restoration procedure without ISR?
column2: The SGW immediately sends a Downlink Data Notification message including the IMSI to the respective MME or S4-SGSN. Depending on the received downlink packet type, the SGW takes specific actions, such as silently discarding user plane data, rejecting control plane messages, or accepting Delete Bearer Request messages.

column1: How does the SGW handle the network triggered service restoration procedure with ISR when it detects the restart of an ISR-associated CN node?
column2: In the network triggered service restoration procedure with ISR, if the SGW detects the restart of an ISR-associated CN node, it maintains all PDN connection table data and MM bearer contexts for both non-failed and restarted ISR-associated nodes. The SGW initiates a timer to control the duration of ISR activation.

column1: What is the SGW's action upon receipt of a downlink user plane or control plane packet on a maintained S5/S8 bearer for a UE in idle mode or connected state with the failed CN node in the network triggered service restoration procedure with ISR?
column2: The SGW initiates the network triggered service request procedure towards the non-failed CN node and immediately sends a Downlink Data Notification message including the IMSI towards the restarted CN node. The SGW continues to forward downlink user plane or control plane packets for a UE in connected state in the non-failed ISR-associated node.

column1: What actions does the non-failed ISR-associated CN node take upon receiving a Cancel Location message from HSS/HLR with "Initial Attach procedure" Cancellation Type?
column2: The non-failed ISR-associated CN node deletes all bearer contexts and sends Delete Session Request message(s) to SGW. The SGW releases all resources for the UE and sends appropriate messages to PGWs involved to release resources. The specific messages depend on whether it's a GTP-based S5/S8 or PMIP-based S5/S8 case.

column1: What procedure does the MME/S4-SGSN follow when it detects a restart of an ISR-associated counterpart?
column2: The MME/S4-SGSN waits for the next RAU/TAU procedure to deactivate ISR. Optionally, it may internally mark ISR as not active. The non-failed CN node may initiate GUTI Relocation or P-TMSI Relocation Procedure to force the UE to perform TAU/RAU procedure for ISR deactivation. After receiving TAU/RAU Request, the MME/S4-SGSN informs the UE to disable ISR in the TAU/RAU Accept message.

column1: How does the SGW handle the timer in the network triggered service restoration procedure with ISR?
column2: The SGW starts a timer upon detecting the restart of an ISR-associated CN node, controlling the duration during which the SGW considers ISR still active. If the timer expires, the SGW deactivates ISR by locally releasing resources for the maintained restarted CN node (i.e., restarted CN node control plane F-TEID).

column1: What is the purpose of the Mobile terminated CS service delivery via an alternative MME in MME pool procedure?
column2: The procedure enables the network to continue delivering mobile terminated CS services to UEs via an alternative MME in the MME pool when the originally registered MME fails without restart or is down for an extended duration.
column3: The provided text outlines procedures for the restoration of PDN (Packet Data Network) connections in the Evolved Packet Core (EPC) of a mobile network after an SGW (Serving Gateway) failure. These procedures are designed to resume the delivery of downlink data towards the User Equipment (UE) with minimal service interruption and signaling in the network. The document specifies optional restoration procedures for UEs with or without ISR (Idle Mode Signaling Reduction) active during SGW failure. The restoration involves selecting a new or restarted SGW and maintaining PDN connections affected by the failure for a configurable period. Different scenarios are considered, such as UEs in idle or connected states, and specific actions are defined for MME/S4-SGSN, SGW, PGW, and PCRF (Policy and Charging Rules Function) entities. Additionally, the text discusses PGW-triggered SGW restoration procedures and provides details on the signaling and acknowledgment messages exchanged between network elements during the restoration process. The procedures aim to ensure efficient network operation and data delivery while taking into account factors like emergency PDN connections and operator policies for restoration prioritization.

column1: What is the purpose of the procedures specified in clause 27 for the restoration of PDN connections after an SGW failure?
column2: The procedures in clause 27 aim to restore PDN connections affected by an SGW failure, ensuring minimal service interruption and signaling in the network.

column1: Which UEs do the procedures in clause 27.2 apply to?
column2: The procedures in clause 27.2 apply to UEs for which ISR (Idle Mode Signaling Reduction) is not active when the SGW fails.

column1: What does the MME/S4-SGSN do in the MME/S4-SGSN triggered SGW restoration procedure (clause 27.2.2.2)?
column2: In the MME/S4-SGSN triggered SGW restoration procedure, the MME/S4-SGSN maintains bearers and MM contexts of PDN connections affected by SGW failure and eligible for restoration, preventing the removal of associated resources.

column1: How does the MME/S4-SGSN prioritize SGW relocation for UEs in clause 27.2.2.2?
column2: The MME/S4-SGSN prioritizes SGW relocation based on factors such as ongoing mobility procedures, GBR bearers, and emergency PDN connections.

column1: What is the role of PGW in the PGW triggered SGW restoration procedure (clause 27.2.3)?
column2: In the PGW triggered SGW restoration procedure, the PGW maintains PDN connections affected by SGW failure and eligible for restoration for a configurable period. It also triggers downlink notifications for eligible PDN connections.

column1: When does the SGW send a PGW Downlink Triggering Notification message in clause 27.2.3.3?
column2: The SGW sends a PGW Downlink Triggering Notification message upon receiving the notification from the PGW, aiming to inform the MME/S4-SGSN about the need for downlink triggering.

column1: What actions does the MME/S4-SGSN take for UEs with ISR in clause 27.3.1.2?
column2: For UEs with ISR, the MME/S4-SGSN, during TAU/RAU procedures, performs SGW relocation and informs the UE to disable ISR. For Service Request procedures, it initiates GUTI Relocation or P-TMSI Relocation procedures for ISR deactivation.

column1: When does a UE become aware of an MME failure in idle mode?
column2: UEs in idle mode become aware of an MME failure when they need to send uplink data or signaling, or when they are forced to re-attach, such as through a network-triggered service restoration procedure.
column3: The procedure outlined in clause 26 describes the optional feature for VLR and MME, allowing the network to sustain mobile terminated CS services to UEs through an alternative MME in the MME pool when the originally registered MME fails or remains inactive for an extended period. UEs in idle mode become aware of an MME failure upon the need for uplink data or signaling, or during forced re-attachment. The VLR, upon paging the UE for CS services, detects the inactive MME and sends an SGs paging request with a CS restoration indicator to an alternative MME, employing load balancing during the restoration. Various conditions guide the MME's response to the SGs paging request, including handling unknown IMSIs, EMM-DEREGISTERED status, and location information. The procedure supports extended idle mode DRX for MT-SMS service, with the MME paging the UE using S-TMSI. The re-attachment process involves establishing a new SGs association with the VLR, potentially a different one, depending on network deployment scenarios. Subsequent MT CS services are delivered according to normal procedures, and specific considerations are provided for scenarios involving ISR activation and paging failures on different interfaces.

column1: What should the VLR do when it has to page the UE for a mobile terminated CS service and detects that the serving MME is no longer in service?
column2: The VLR should send an SGs paging request with a CS restoration indicator to one alternative MME in the same MME pool and load-balance the paging requests among available MMEs during the restoration procedure.

column1: How can the VLR know the set of MMEs belonging to the same MME pool?
column2: The VLR may know the set of MMEs pertaining to the same MME pool either by local configuration or by checking the MME Group ID within the MME name signaled to the VLR in certain messages.

column1: What action should the MME take upon receiving an SGs paging request including the CS restoration indicator?
column2: The MME should accept the SGs paging request and proceed based on the IMSI's status and location information. Actions include paging the UE in specific tracking areas or rejecting the request per operator policy.

column1: In what cases does the MME page the UE using the S-TMSI for extended idle mode DRX for MT-SMS service?
column2: The MME may page the UE using the S-TMSI for extended idle mode DRX for MT-SMS service, and the procedure is implementation-dependent.

column1: What happens if the UE receives a Service Reject with Cause #10 – Implicitly detached during paging by an alternative MME with the S-TMSI?
column2: The UE re-attaches to the network, and a new SGs association is established with the VLR. The VLR may repeat the SGs paging request if the new SGs association is established towards the same VLR.

column1: How are subsequent MT CS services delivered if the new SGs association is established towards a different VLR?
column2: Subsequent MT CS services may be delivered via the new VLR using Mobile Terminating Roaming Retry or Mobile Terminating Roaming Forwarding; ongoing MT SMS is retransmitted by the SMS-SC using existing SMS procedures.

column1: What happens if a UE with ISR active before the MME failure and using GERAN or UTRAN radio access does not respond to a first paging on the SGs interface?
column2: The VLR can deliver the MT CS service by paging the UE on the A/Iu interface as per existing principles of 3GPP TS 29.118 when the UE does not respond to a first paging on the SGs interface.

column1: What is the mandatory action that a CSS must perform for subscriber data records affected by a CSS fault during a restart?
column2: The CSS must reload all data from the non-volatile backup, send a "Reset" message to each VLR, and send a "Reset" message to each SGSN and MME.
column3: The document outlines procedures related to the restoration of data in the CSS, the MBMS Heartbeat procedure, and the restoration of the SCEF.
