column2: The MS uses Access Technology information to determine what type(s) of radio carrier to search for when attempting to select a specific PLMN (Public Land Mobile Network) or SNPN (Stand-alone Non-Public Network).

column1: How is an "Allowable PLMN" defined for an MS operating in MS operation mode A or B?
column2: For an MS operating in MS operation mode A or B, an Allowable PLMN is a PLMN that is allowable, and the specific access technology is supporting non-GPRS services or supporting GPRS services.

column1: What does "Camped on a cell" mean in the context of the document?
column2: Camped on a cell refers to the MS (Mobile Station) completing the cell selection/reselection process and choosing a cell from which it plans to receive all available services.

column1: What is the purpose of camping on a cell in idle mode?
column2: The purpose of camping on a cell in idle mode is fourfold: a) It enables the MS to receive system information from the PLMN or SNPN. b) If the MS wishes to initiate a call, it can do this by initially accessing the network on the control channel of the cell on which it is camped. c) If the PLMN or SNPN receives a call for the MS, it knows (in most cases) the registration area of the cell in which the MS is camped. It can then send a "paging" message for the MS on control channels of all the cells in the registration area. d) It enables the MS to receive cell broadcast messages.
column3: In the general description of idle mode, when a mobile station (MS) is switched on, it seeks connection with a public land mobile network (PLMN) or a stand-alone non-public network (SNPN). This selection can be automatic or manual. The MS looks for a suitable cell within the chosen PLMN or SNPN, camps on it, and registers its presence if necessary. If coverage is lost or a more suitable cell is found, reselection occurs. If the MS loses connection to a PLMN or SNPN, it may automatically select a new one or notify the user for manual selection. Registration is not needed for MSs providing services not requiring registration. The purpose of camping on a cell in idle mode includes receiving system information, initiating calls, responding to incoming calls, and receiving cell broadcast messages. If a suitable cell is not found, the MS may attempt to camp on any available cell in a "limited service" state, allowing only emergency calls. Different modes such as eCall only mode or A/Gb mode have specific behaviors during idle mode. The idle mode tasks involve PLMN, SNPN, CSG, cell, location registration, CTS fixed part, and CAG selection. The subsequent section outlines requirements and technical solutions, including PLMN selection modes, forbidden areas, and handling of reject messages with specific cause values. Various timers and lists are maintained for efficient PLMN selection and service availability, with considerations for different access technologies and network scenarios.

column1: How does the MS handle PLMN selection in automatic mode?
column2: In automatic mode, the MS utilizes a list of PLMN/access technology combinations in priority order. The highest priority PLMN/access technology combination that is available and allowable is selected.

column1: What actions does the MS take in response to a reject message with cause value #78 "PLMNs not allowed to operate at the present UE location"?
column2: Depending on the mode in which the message was received, the MS takes different actions:In A/Gb mode or Iu mode, the location area is added to the list of "forbidden location areas for roaming," and the MS searches for a suitable cell in the same PLMN but belonging to an LA or TA not in the forbidden list.In S1-mode, the tracking area is added to the list of "forbidden tracking areas for roaming," and the MS searches for a suitable cell in the same PLMN but belonging to a TA or LA not in the forbidden list.In N1-mode, the tracking area is added to the list of "5GS forbidden tracking areas for roaming," and the MS searches for a suitable cell in the same PLMN but belonging to a tracking area not in the forbidden list.

column1: What is the difference between automatic and manual modes in PLMN selection?
column2: In automatic mode, the MS selects the highest priority PLMN/access technology combination available and allowable from a predefined list. In contrast, in manual mode, the MS indicates to the user which PLMNs are available, and it only tries to obtain normal service on the visited PLMN when the user makes a manual selection.

column1: How does the MS handle a reject message with cause value #15 in A/Gb mode or Iu mode?
column2: In A/Gb mode or Iu mode, if the MS receives a reject message with cause value #15, it adds the location area to the list of "forbidden location areas for roaming." The MS then searches for a suitable cell in the same PLMN but belonging to an LA or TA not in the forbidden list.

column1: What is the purpose of the "forbidden PLMNs for GPRS service" list in manual or automatic mode?
column2: In manual or automatic mode, the "forbidden PLMNs for GPRS service" list is used when a message with cause value "GPRS services not allowed in this PLMN" or "EPS services not allowed in this PLMN" is received by the MS. The VPLMN causing the reject is added to this list, and the MS deletes entries when there is a successful GPRS attach, routing area update, EPS attach, tracking area update, or registration procedure.

column1: How does the MS handle PLMN selection when E-UTRA capability is re-enabled?
column2: If the MS re-enables its E-UTRA capability during PLMN selection, it memorizes the PLMNs where E-UTRA capability was disabled as PLMNs where voice service was not possible in E-UTRAN. In automatic PLMN selection, it does not consider such PLMNs for E-UTRA access technology unless no other PLMN is available. The stored information is deleted when the MS is switched off, the USIM is removed, timer TD expires, or MS voice domain configuration changes.

column1: What are the two modes of CSG selection, and how does the Automatic mode impact the MS when selecting a cell in a PLMN?
column2: The two modes of CSG selection are Automatic mode and Manual mode. In the Automatic mode, the MS utilizes the Allowed CSG list and the Operator CSG list. When selecting a cell in a PLMN, the MS camps on a cell only if it is either not a CSG cell or is a CSG cell with a CSG identity that is in the Allowed CSG list or the Operator CSG List.
column3: In the context of cellular network selection and restriction, the document outlines procedures related to Closed Subscriber Group (CSG) selection and restriction, as well as Public Land Mobile Network (PLMN) selection triggered by different communication scenarios. In the case of CSG selection, the Mobile Station (MS) supports both automatic and manual modes. Automatic mode relies on Allowed CSG and Operator CSG lists, ensuring the MS camps on a cell based on specified criteria. Manual mode involves user interaction, where the MS presents available CSGs, and the selection is restricted based on configuration. PLMN selection can be triggered by ProSe, V2X communication over PC5, or A2X communication over PC5. The MS follows specific steps, considering conditions like radio resources provisioned, authorized PLMNs, and network rejections, updating forbidden lists as needed. The document emphasizes limited service states for communication modes, handling registration failures, and returning to stored duplicate values in various scenarios. The detailed procedures provide a comprehensive guide for network and communication management in different contexts.

column1: Explain the conditions under which the MS shall attempt to register on a PLMN when triggered by ProSe communications, and what actions are taken if the registration fails.
column2: When triggered by ProSe communications, the MS attempts to register on a PLMN if it meets specific conditions, such as providing radio resources for ProSe communications and being in the list of authorized PLMNs for ProSe communications. If the registration fails due to reasons like "PLMN not allowed" or "EPS services not allowed," the MS updates the forbidden PLMNs list. The MS may then perform ProSe communications in limited service state on the selected PLMN, return to the stored duplicate PLMN selection mode, or retry PLMN selection with different choices.

column1: In the context of PLMN selection triggered by V2X communication over PC5, describe the criteria for choosing an allowable PLMN and the subsequent actions if the registration fails.
column2: When triggered by V2X communication over PC5, the MS chooses an allowable PLMN based on conditions such as providing radio resources for V2X communication and being in the list of authorized PLMNs. If the registration fails due to "PLMN not allowed" or "EPS services not allowed," the MS updates the forbidden PLMNs list. The MS may then perform V2X communication in limited service state, return to the stored duplicate PLMN selection mode, or retry PLMN selection with different choices.

column1: What steps does the MS take when performing PLMN selection for A2X communication over PC5, and how does it handle registration failures?
column2: During PLMN selection for A2X communication over PC5, the MS chooses an allowable PLMN based on criteria such as providing radio resources for A2X communication and being in the list of authorized PLMNs. If the registration fails due to reasons like "PLMN not allowed" or "EPS services not allowed," the MS updates the forbidden PLMNs list. The MS may then perform A2X communication in limited service state, return to the stored duplicate PLMN selection mode, or retry PLMN selection with different choices.

column1: What are the actions taken by an MS in A/Gb mode or Iu mode when it receives a message with cause value #12 due to attempting to camp on a cell with forbidden LA identity?
column2: In A/Gb mode or Iu mode, if an MS receives a message with cause value #12 indicating an attempt to camp on a cell with a forbidden LA identity, it stores the forbidden LA identity in a list of "forbidden location areas for regional provision of service." This list is periodically deleted or upon the MS being switched off, the SIM being removed, or other specified conditions. Subsequently, the MS enters the limited service state.
column3: The provided text outlines protocols and procedures related to regional provision of service for mobile stations (MS) within a telecommunication network. It discusses scenarios where an MS may have regionally restricted service, detailing the actions the MS should take in different modes (A/Gb mode, Iu mode, S1-mode, N1-mode) when attempting to access a cell in an area for which it lacks service entitlement. The text also covers borders between registration areas, access control mechanisms, forbidden location areas for regional provision of service, and conditions leading to a limited service state. Additionally, it addresses scenarios where an MS may be unable to obtain normal service from a Public Land Mobile Network (PLMN) or Selected NPN (SNPN), such as failure to find a suitable cell, SIM-related issues, and responses to specific LR requests. Furthermore, it discusses procedures related to Circuit Switched (CS) fixed part selection in A/Gb mode, NAS (Non-Access Stratum) behavior configuration, CAG (Closed Access Group) selection in N1 mode, and SNPN selection, including modes for automatic and manual SNPN selection. Overall, the text provides a detailed overview of the network-related behaviors and actions of an MS in various scenarios and modes.

column1: How does an MS handle forbidden TA identity in S1-mode during regional provision of service?
column2: In S1-mode, when an MS encounters a forbidden TA identity during regional provision of service, it stores the forbidden TA identity in a list of "forbidden tracking areas for regional provision of service." Similar to A/Gb mode, this list is periodically deleted or upon specific events. The MS then enters the limited service state.

column1: What does the document specify about PLMN selection for a multi-mode MS supporting both 3GPP and 3GPP2 systems?
column2: The document defines PLMN selection logic for a multi-mode MS supporting both 3GPP and 3GPP2 systems. It outlines conditions, common PLMN selection logic, and procedures for using CSG and CAG cells. Additionally, the document details SNPN selection and implements idle mode operation requirements from the 22 series Technical Specifications.

column1: How does the document address the handling of CAG (Closed Access Group) information in N1 mode?
column2: In N1 mode, the document specifies that the MS may support CAG and, if so, can be provisioned by the network with a "CAG information list." This list includes PLMN IDs, an "Allowed CAG list" with associated CAG-IDs, and an optional indication that the MS is only allowed to access 5GS via CAG cells. The document provides detailed procedures for handling CAG information and its relevance during PLMN selection.

column1: What actions does an MS take when it is in the limited service state, and no suitable cell is available?
column2: In the limited service state, when no suitable cell is available, the document outlines various scenarios such as attempting to make emergency calls, initiating ProSe and V2X communications, and specific actions for SNPN access operation mode. The MS follows detailed procedures based on its configuration, including SNPN selection, emergency services, and PLMN selection under specific conditions.

column1: How does the document recommend handling situations where the MS is moving in a border area between registration areas?
column2: The document addresses the challenge of an MS moving in a border area between registration areas. To prevent excessive signaling load, it recommends that the access stratum provides a mechanism to limit registration area changes. The criteria C1_CTS and C2_CTS are introduced to manage CTS (Closed Transport System) attachments, ensuring efficient operation in such border areas.

column1: What is the significance of the NAS behavior configuration, and how can it be operator-configurable?
column2: NAS behavior configuration is crucial, and the document highlights its operator configurability using parameters in the USIM or the ME. The NAS behavior can be adjusted based on operator preferences, and the document specifies precedence rules when parameters are available in both the USIM and the ME.

column1: In A/Gb mode, what actions does the document recommend for an MS configured for Emergency Access Barring (EAB) in response to specific events?
column2: In A/Gb mode, the document specifies actions for an MS configured for Emergency Access Barring (EAB). It details how the MS responds to events such as initiating emergency calls, responding to paging, and starting various multimedia services, with specific conditions for overriding EAB in certain situations.

column1: How does the document guide the MS in handling forbidden LA or TA during regional provision of service?
column2: The document outlines that an MS is not allowed to initiate a CM connection or request GPRS/5GS services when camped on a cell with a forbidden LA or TA for regional provision of service. However, the MS may still respond to paging messages. The document provides clear directives on the permissible actions under these conditions.

column1: What considerations and procedures does the document specify for CTS (Closed Transport System) fixed part selection in A/Gb mode?
column2: In A/Gb mode, the document addresses CTS fixed part selection, emphasizing that the CTS MS should periodically attempt to select a CTS fixed part if it loses CTS coverage. It describes the criteria for attaching to a CTS fixed part and how the CTS MS should handle changes in CTS coverage in border areas.

column1: What is Minimization of Service Interruption (MINT) in the context of MS (Mobile Station)?
column2: Minimization of Service Interruption (MINT) is a feature that may be supported by the Mobile Station (MS) in a PLMN (Public Land Mobile Network). However, MINT is not applicable in SNPNs (Service Network Provider Networks). When the MS supports MINT, it can be provisioned by the network with various parameters and settings related to disaster roaming services.
column3: In the context of the provided technical specifications (3.10 Minimization of Service Interruption and 3.11 Signal Level Enhanced Network Selection), the Minimization of Service Interruption (MINT) feature is discussed, outlining conditions and procedures for disaster roaming services in Public Land Mobile Networks (PLMNs). If a Mobile Station (MS) supports MINT, it can be provisioned by the network with various parameters, including disaster roaming settings, wait ranges, and lists of PLMNs to be used in disaster conditions. These parameters are stored in the non-volatile memory of the Mobile Equipment (ME) or pre-configured in the Universal Subscriber Identity Module (USIM). The technical specifications further detail scenarios for updating and deleting these parameters, considering events such as USIM insertion and USAT REFRESH commands. Additionally, the Signal Level Enhanced Network Selection feature is introduced, specifying conditions under which an MS, supporting specific technologies, applies enhanced network selection based on operator-controlled signal thresholds stored in the USIM. The Home PLMN can update these thresholds, and the feature is intended for IoT stationary devices, with provisions for subsequent PLMN selections based on updated thresholds.

column1: What information can the MS be provisioned with if it supports Minimization of Service Interruption (MINT)?
column2: If the MS supports Minimization of Service Interruption (MINT), the network can provision it with: a) An indication of whether disaster roaming is enabled in the UE (User Equipment), provided by the HPLMN (Home PLMN). b) A list of PLMN(s) to be used in disaster conditions, provided by the HPLMN, with priorities assigned to each PLMN. c) Lists of PLMN(s) to be used in disaster conditions provided by a VPLMN (Visited PLMN), with priorities assigned to each PLMN. d) Disaster roaming wait range and disaster return wait range, each consisting of a minimum and maximum wait time. e) An indication of the applicability of "lists of PLMN(s) to be used in disaster condition" provided by a VPLMN.

column1: How is the network information related to disaster roaming stored in the Mobile Station (MS)?
column2: The network may provide information related to disaster roaming, including the "list of PLMN(s) to be used in disaster condition," disaster roaming wait range, disaster return wait range, and other indications during registration or configuration procedures. This information is stored in the non-volatile memory of the Mobile Equipment (ME) as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [64] annex C. Additionally, the MS can be pre-configured with this information stored in the USIM (Universal Subscriber Identity Module).

column1: Under what conditions does the Mobile Station (MS) delete the stored information related to disaster roaming?
column2: The conditions under which the MS deletes stored information related to disaster roaming, such as whether disaster roaming is enabled, the lists of PLMN(s) for disaster conditions, disaster roaming wait range, and disaster return wait range, are specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [64] annex C. The deletion may occur when a USIM is inserted or when the ME receives a USAT REFRESH command indicating updates to the stored information.

column1: What actions does the Mobile Station (MS) take upon selecting a PLMN for disaster roaming?
column2: Upon selecting a PLMN for disaster roaming, if a disaster roaming wait range is stored in the ME, the MS generates a random number within this range and starts a timer. During the timer's duration, the MS refrains from initiating registration except for emergency services. After the timer expires, if no emergency PDU session is active, the MS may initiate registration. If an emergency PDU session exists, the MS initiates registration after releasing the emergency PDU session.

column1: What conditions must be fulfilled for Signal Level Enhanced Network Selection to apply in a Mobile Station (MS) supporting NB-IoT, GERAN EC-GSM-IoT, and E-UTRA Category M1 or M2?
column2: Signal Level Enhanced Network Selection applies to an MS supporting NB-IoT, GERAN EC-GSM-IoT, and E-UTRA Category M1 or M2 when the following conditions are fulfilled: The MS is in automatic PLMN selection mode. The MS supports the "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology" specified in 3GPP TS 22.011 [19]. The MS is configured for using signal level enhanced network selection as specified in 3GPP TS 24.368 [50]. The MS is configured for using signal level enhanced network selection as specified in 3GPP TS 31.102 [40]. The "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology" is configured in the USIM as specified in 3GPP TS 31.102 [40].

column1: What information can be configured in the "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology" stored in the USIM for Signal Level Enhanced Network Selection?
column2: The "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology" stored in the USIM can consist of entries, each containing a home operator controlled signal threshold and an access technology. This information is specific to a certain access technology and applies to all allowable PLMNs with the corresponding access technology combination.

column1: How can the HPLMN update the "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology" in a Mobile Station (MS)?
column2: The HPLMN can update the "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology" via steering of roaming information. When the ME receives a USAT REFRESH command indicating updates to this information, an MS that applies Signal Level Enhanced Network Selection shall use the updated thresholds provided by the HPLMN for subsequent PLMN selections.

column1: What is the intended usage of the "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology," and which devices is it expected to be supported by?
column2: The "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology" is intended for IoT stationary devices (as specified in 3GPP TS 22.011 [19]). It is not expected to be supported by non-IoT devices.

column1: What is the aim of the idle mode processes?
column2: The aim of the idle mode processes is to ensure that the registered PLMN is the selected PLMN and that the registered SNPN is the selected SNPN.

column1: How is the overall state of the mobile defined in the context of PLMN and SNPN processes?
column2: The overall state of the mobile is a composite of the states of PLMN selection, SNPN selection, cell selection, and location registration processes.

column1: When may an event in one process trigger a change of state in another process?
column2: An event causing a change of state in one process may trigger a change of state in another process, for example, camping on a cell in a new registration area triggers a location registration request.

column1: What is the significance of the states A1 to A6 in the PLMN selection process in automatic mode?
column2: States A1 to A6 in automatic mode represent different scenarios such as trying to perform a location registration, successfully registering on a PLMN, attempting to register on a PLMN in the ordered list, waiting for PLMNs to appear, searching for the HPLMN, and having no SIM.

column1: In manual mode, what does state M3 signify in the PLMN selection process?
column2: In manual mode, state M3 signifies that the mobile station (MS) has failed to register on the selected PLMN.

column1: What are the conditions for an MS to successfully register on a PLMN in both automatic and manual modes?
column2: For an MS to successfully register on a PLMN, it must find a suitable cell of the PLMN to camp on, and an LR request from the MS must be accepted in the registration area of the cell.

column1: What information does the Mobile Equipment (ME) utilize for PLMN selection, and how is the priority determined?
column2: The ME utilizes information stored in the SIM, such as "HPLMN Selector with Access Technology" and "Operator Controlled PLMN Selector with Access Technology." Priority is determined based on the specified order in these data files.

column1: How does the MS perform PLMN selection at switch-on or recovery from lack of coverage in automatic mode?
column2: At switch-on, the MS selects the registered PLMN or equivalent PLMN (if available) using all access technologies. If signal level enhanced network selection is applicable, it considers the received signal quality from a candidate PLMN/access technology combination.

column1: What is the purpose of the Automatic Network Selection Mode Procedure?
column2: The Automatic Network Selection Mode Procedure involves the MS selecting and attempting registration on other PLMN/access technology combinations in a specified order, considering factors such as HPLMN, user-controlled PLMN selector, operator-controlled PLMN selector, signal quality, and disaster roaming services.

column1: Under what conditions does the MS enter the state "LR pending" in the location registration process?
column2: The MS enters the "LR pending" state after starting the LR process and is waiting for the outcome, specifically, a response message from the network.

column1: What should an MS in eCall only mode do if it cannot select any PLMN according to l)?
column2: An MS in eCall only mode that cannot select any PLMN according to l) can perform a second iteration of i to v with no restriction.

column1: In which scenarios should the MS consider a PLMN indicated by an NG-RAN cell if it supports CAG and is provisioned with a non-empty "CAG information list"?
column2: The MS should consider a PLMN indicated by an NG-RAN cell if it supports CAG and is provisioned with a non-empty "CAG information list" under the following conditions:The cell is a CAG cell and broadcasts a CAG-ID for the PLMN with authorization based on the "Allowed CAG list" of the entry.The cell is not a CAG cell, and there is no entry with the PLMN ID of the PLMN in the "CAG information list" or the entry does not include the "indication that the MS is only allowed to access 5GS via CAG cells."

column1: What action should the MS take if it supports CIoT 5GS optimizations and cannot select any PLMN according to o)?
column2: As an implementation option, the MS supporting CIoT 5GS optimizations that cannot select any PLMN according to o) can perform a second iteration of i to v with no restriction.

column1: When does the MS use the PLMN/access technology combination in the "Operator Controlled PLMN Selector with Access Technology" stored in the ME in iii)?
column2: In iii), the MS shall use the PLMN/access technology combination in the "Operator Controlled PLMN Selector with Access Technology" stored in the ME if the last update of the "Operator Controlled PLMN Selector with Access Technology" was due to receiving steering of roaming information containing the "list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations."

column1: How does the MS determine the MS determined PLMN with disaster condition in q1) for vi and vii?
column2: A: The MS determines the MS determined PLMN with disaster condition in q1) for vi and vii as follows:If the MS's RPLMN is included in any "list of one or more PLMN(s) with disaster condition for which disaster roaming services is offered by the available PLMN," the MS considers that the MS's RPLMN is the MS determined PLMN with disaster condition.If the MS's RPLMN is not included or not allowable, the MS determines the MS determined PLMN with disaster condition from allowable PLMNs in a specified order.

column1: Under what conditions does the MS perform vi and vii to select a PLMN for disaster roaming services?
column2: The MS performs vi and vii to select a PLMN for disaster roaming services only if it supports MINT, disaster roaming is enabled in the UE, there is no available allowable PLMN, and certain conditions related to NG-RAN cell broadcasting are met.

column1: In which scenario does the MS not consider PLMNs if it supports NR RedCap and camps on an NR cell connected to 5GCN?
column2: The MS does not consider PLMNs if it supports NR RedCap and camps on an NR cell connected to 5GCN.

column1: What should the MS do in i to vii if it detects a forbidden PLMN in satellite NG-RAN access technology?
column2: In i to vii, if the MS detects a forbidden PLMN in satellite NG-RAN access technology, it shall not consider the PLMN as a PLMN selection candidate for satellite NG-RAN access technology.

column1: What conditions trigger the MS to stop applying signal level enhanced network selection in v)?
column2: The MS shall stop applying signal level enhanced network selection in v) if signal level enhanced network selection is applicable, and the received signal quality of the candidate PLMN/access technology combination is lower than the threshold value indicated for the access technology in the "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology."

column1: What does the MS indicate to the user if it cannot achieve successful registration and does not support access to RLOS?
column2: If successful registration cannot be achieved, and the MS does not support access to RLOS, the MS indicates "no service" to the user, waits until a new PLMN is available and allowable, and then repeats the procedure.

column1: What conditions must be met for the MS to consider a PLMN indicated by an NG-RAN cell when the MS supports CAG and is provisioned with a non-empty "CAG information list"?
column2: The MS must consider a PLMN indicated by an NG-RAN cell when the MS supports CAG and is provisioned with a non-empty "CAG information list" if: The cell is a CAG cell and broadcasts a CAG-ID for the PLMN. There exists an entry with the PLMN ID of the PLMN in the "CAG information list," and the CAG-ID is authorized based on the "Allowed CAG list" of the entry.

column1: What should the MS consider when it only supports control plane CIoT 5GS optimization and camps on an E-UTRA cell connected to 5GCN, which is not an NB-IoT cell?
column2: When the MS only supports control plane CIoT 5GS optimization and camps on an E-UTRA cell connected to 5GCN (not an NB-IoT cell):The MS shall not consider PLMNs that do not advertise support of 5GS services with control plane CIoT 5GS optimization.

column1: In which situations should the MS perform vi and vii to select a PLMN for disaster roaming services?
column2: The MS should perform vi and vii to select a PLMN for disaster roaming services only if: The MS supports MINT. The indication of whether disaster roaming is enabled in the UE stored in the ME is set to "Disaster roaming is enabled in the UE." There is no available PLMN that is allowable. The MS is not in 5GMM-REGISTERED state and 5GMM-CONNECTED mode over non-3GPP access. The MS does not have a PDN connection via an ePDG connected to EPC.

column1: Under what conditions does the MS enter a limited service state?
column2: The MS enters a limited service state under the following conditions:If no PLMNs are available and allowable, and the MS does not support access to RLOS, the MS indicates "no service" to the user. If an LR failure prevents registration on available and allowable PLMNs or an entry in certain lists prevents a registration attempt, the MS selects the first such PLMN again and enters a limited service state.

column1: When does the MS automatically register on a different PLMN after manual network selection?
column2: The MS may automatically register on a different PLMN after manual network selection if: The MS supports MINT. The "list of PLMN(s) to be used in disaster condition" is non-empty. There is no available PLMN declared as an equivalent PLMN by the RPLMN. The RPLMN of the MS is considered as the MS determined PLMN with disaster condition.

column1: What actions should the MS take if the user does not select a PLMN during the PLMN selection procedure?
column2: If the user does not select a PLMN, the selected PLMN shall be the one that was selected before the PLMN selection procedure started. If no such PLMN was selected or that PLMN is no longer available, the MS shall attempt to camp on any acceptable cell and enter the limited service state.

column1: Under what conditions should manual CSG selection not be performed?
column2: Manual CSG selection should not be performed if the MS has a PDN connection for emergency bearer services.

column1: How does the MS handle the situation when the user selects a CSG within the RPLMN whose CSG identity is not included in the Allowed CSG list or Operator CSG list?
column2: If the user selects a CSG within the RPLMN whose CSG identity is not included in the Allowed CSG list or Operator CSG list, the MS shall attempt to register on a cell that corresponds to the CSG. After registration, the MS shall return to automatic CSG selection mode, regardless of the registration outcome.

column1: What actions does the MS take when the user selects a CSG in a PLMN different from the RPLMN?
column2: When the user selects a CSG in a PLMN different from the RPLMN, the MS takes the following actions: i) The MS stores a duplicate of the RPLMN and a duplicate of the PLMN selection mode before the manual CSG selection, unless this manual CSG selection follows another manual CSG selection, a PLMN selection triggered by ProSe communications, a PLMN selection triggered by V2X communication over PC5, or a PLMN selection triggered by A2X communication over PC5. ii) The MS enters Manual mode of PLMN selection in state M4 (Trying PLMN). iii) The MS selects the PLMN corresponding to the CSG and attempts to register on the selected CSG cell in the PLMN. If successful, the MS remains in manual CSG selection mode until the user selects automatic CSG selection mode, the MS is switched off, or specific conditions are met (items iv to viii). iv) If the registration fails or the MS is no longer in the coverage of the selected CSG, the MS returns to the stored duplicate PLMN selection mode and automatic CSG selection mode, using the stored duplicate value of RPLMN for further action. v) If the MS is switched off while on the selected CSG and switched on again, it returns to the stored duplicate PLMN selection mode, unless the MS provides the optional feature of user preferred PLMN selection operating mode at switch-on. Additionally, the MS uses the stored duplicate value of RPLMN and automatic CSG selection mode for further action. vi) If the user initiates a PLMN selection while on the selected CSG, the MS deletes the stored duplicate PLMN selection mode, uses the stored duplicate value of RPLMN as RPLMN, returns to automatic CSG selection mode, and follows the procedures specified in clause 4.4.3.1. vii) If the MS's E-UTRA capability is disabled due to successful registration and the selected CSG is not available on UTRAN radio access technology, the MS re-enables the E-UTRA capability, returns to the stored duplicate PLMN selection mode and automatic CSG selection mode, using the stored duplicate value of RPLMN for further action. viii) If the MS's E-UTRA capability is disabled due to performing the service request procedure, the selected CSG is not available on UTRAN radio access technology, and the MS performed a CS call, then after the call ends, the MS re-enables the E-UTRA capability, returns to the stored duplicate PLMN selection mode and automatic CSG selection mode, using the stored duplicate value of RPLMN for further action.

column1: What is the procedure for automatic network selection mode when the MS initiates reselection and registration?
column2: In automatic network selection mode, when the user initiates reselection and registration, the MS follows the following procedures: i) Attempts registration on PLMN/access technology combinations in the following order: a) HPLMN (or the highest priority EHPLMN if the EHPLMN list is present and not empty). b) PLMN/access technology combinations in the "User Controlled PLMN Selector with Access Technology" data file in the SIM (excluding the previously selected combination). c) PLMN/access technology combinations in the "Operator Controlled PLMN Selector with Access Technology" data file in the SIM or stored in the ME (excluding the previously selected combination). d) Other PLMN/access technology combinations with the received high-quality signal in random order (excluding the previously selected combination). e) Other PLMN/access technology combinations in order of decreasing signal quality or the previously selected combination, ignoring its signal quality. ii) The equivalent PLMNs list is not applied to user reselection in automatic network selection mode.

column1: What is the interpretation of timer T for an MS supporting both EC-GSM-IoT, Category M1, or Category NB1 and other access technologies?
column2: For an MS supporting both EC-GSM-IoT, Category M1, or Category NB1 and other access technologies: If the MS is using EC-GSM-IoT, Category M1, or Category NB1 at the time of starting timer T, T is either in the range of 2 hours to 240 hours, using 2-hour steps from 2 hours to 80 hours and 4-hour steps from 84 hours to 240 hours, or it indicates no periodic attempts. The default value for T is 72 hours if no value is stored in the SIM. If the MS is not using EC-GSM-IoT, Category M1, or Category NB1 at the time of starting timer T, T is either in the range of 6 minutes to 8 hours in 6-minute steps, or it indicates no periodic attempts. If the MS is using satellite NG-RAN access technology or satellite E-UTRAN access technology with a shared MCC at the time of starting timer T, T is in the range of 6 multiplied by integer M minutes to 8 multiplied by integer M hours in 6 multiplied by integer M minutes steps, with a default value of M equal to one if no value is stored in the SIM. If no value for T is stored in the SIM, a default value of 60 minutes is used for T.

column1: Under what conditions does the MS not stop timer T?
column2: The MS does not stop timer T when: It activates power-saving mode (PSM) or mobile-initiated connection only mode (MICO) as described in 3GPP TS 23.682 [27A] or discontinuous coverage due to discontinuous reception. The access stratum is deactivated due to discontinuous coverage (as specified in 3GPP TS 23.401 [58] and 3GPP TS 24.301 [23A]).It activates unavailability period as described in 3GPP TS 24.501 [64].

column1: Under what conditions is Fast First Higher Priority PLMN search enabled, and what actions does the MS take during attempts to access the HPLMN, EHPLMN, or higher priority PLMN?
column2: Fast First Higher Priority PLMN search is enabled if the corresponding configuration parameter is present and set to enabled. The MS takes the following actions during attempts to access the HPLMN, EHPLMN, or higher priority PLMN: a) Periodic attempts are performed in automatic mode when the MS is roaming and not attached for emergency bearer services, registered for emergency services, has a PDU session for emergency services, or has a PDN connection for emergency bearer services. b) The first attempt is made after a period of at least 2 minutes and at most the time configured for T:

column1: What are the conditions and procedures for automatic and manual network selection modes when the MS is registered for disaster roaming services?
column2: When the MS is registered for disaster roaming services: Periodic attempts to obtain service on an allowable PLMN of the same country as the current serving PLMN are performed in accordance with the Automatic Network Selection Mode in clause 4.4.3.1.1. Timer T is either in the range of 30 minutes to 40 hours in 30-minute steps, or it indicates no periodic attempts shall be made, with a default value of 60 minutes if not stored in the SIM. Attempts are made in automatic mode when the MS is registered for disaster roaming services and does not have a PDU session for emergency services. The first attempt is made after a period of at least 2 minutes and at most the time configured for T upon selecting a VPLMN for disaster roaming. Subsequent attempts are made if the MS is registered for disaster roaming services at time T after the last attempt. Periodic attempts are performed only in idle mode or 5GMM-CONNECTED mode with RRC inactive indication. Attempts may be postponed under various conditions, including power saving mode (PSM), eMBMS transport service, broadcast MBS service, eDRX, relaxed monitoring, Mobile Initiated Connection Only mode (MICO), and unavailability period activation. The MS limits attempts to access allowable PLMN/access technology combinations of the same country as the current serving VPLMN. Exceptions apply for satellite NG-RAN access or satellite E-UTRAN access with a shared MCC.

column1: What is the procedure for Manual CSG selection?
column2: The procedure for Manual CSG selection follows the steps outlined in clause 4.4.3.1.3.3. When the user selects a CSG in a PLMN different from the RPLMN, the MS performs actions such as storing duplicates, entering Manual mode of PLMN selection, attempting to register on the selected CSG cell, and handling various scenarios based on successful registration, failure, or specific conditions.

column1: Describe the conditions and actions involved in the Investigation Scan for higher prioritized PLMN.
column2: The Investigation Scan for higher prioritized PLMN is performed when indicated in the SIM, and it is mandatory if the ME supports GSM COMPACT. The MS, capable of both GSM voice and packet service, investigates if there is service from a higher prioritized PLMN not offering GSM voice service (HPLMN, EHPLMNs, or PLMN in a "PLMN Selector with Access Technology" data file on the SIM). The scan follows the requirements of automatic network selection mode, excluding specific conditions related to periodic attempts and the first attempt. The investigation scan is triggered after each successful PLMN selection and registration when the MS is in idle mode and may rely on information from the previous PLMN selection. Additionally, the scan is performed when the MS is unable to obtain normal service from a PLMN, and it may rely on stored information to avoid unnecessary rescans.

column1: Under what conditions does the investigation scan take place, and what actions does the MS take after performing the investigation scan?
column2: The investigation scan takes place only in automatic selection mode and is performed by an MS capable of both voice and packet data. It is initiated if the selected PLMN is not already the highest prioritized PLMN in the current country (HPLMN in home country, otherwise according to PLMN selector lists). After performing the investigation scan, the MS returns to the RPLMN. If a higher prioritized PLMN not offering GSM voice service is found, this information is indicated to the user, but the MS does not automatically select the PLMN unless requested by the user.

column1: Describe the conditions and procedures for periodic attempts related to signal level enhanced network selection. What factors trigger these attempts, and what actions does the MS take during these attempts?
column2: Periodic attempts for signal level enhanced network selection are triggered under the following conditions: Signal level enhanced network selection is applicable (see clause 3.11).The received signal quality of the registered PLMN observed over an averaging window is lower than the "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology." The procedures are as follows: a) Periodic attempts are performed only in automatic mode and not while the MS is attached for emergency bearer services, registered for emergency services, has a PDN connection for emergency bearer services, or has a PDU session for emergency services. b) The MS starts timer TSENSE if the received signal quality of the current cell of the registered PLMN is below the "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology" either upon registration or any time later. c) If, upon expiry of timer TSENSE, the received signal quality of the registered PLMN observed over an averaging window is equal to or greater than the "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology," the MS stays on the current selected PLMN. d) If the received signal quality of the registered PLMN and all other available and allowable PLMN/access technology combinations are lower than the "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology," the MS stops applying signal level enhanced network selection and repeats the network selection procedure. e) Periodic attempts are performed only in idle mode or 5GMM-CONNECTED mode with RRC inactive indication. f) Attempts may be postponed under various conditions, including power saving mode (PSM), discontinuous coverage, eMBMS transport service, eDRX, relaxed monitoring, and Mobile Initiated Connection Only mode (MICO). g) The MS limits attempts to access allowable PLMN/access technology combinations of the same country as the current serving VPLMN, with exceptions for certain scenarios involving satellite NG-RAN access or satellite E-UTRAN access.

column1: What actions does the MS take in abnormal cases, such as when there is no SIM, an authentication failure, or an "IMSI unknown in HLR" response?
column2: In abnormal cases: If there is no SIM in the MS, an authentication failure occurs, or the MS receives an "IMSI unknown in HLR," "illegal ME," or "illegal MS" response to an LR request, effectively, there is no selected PLMN, and the MS enters the "No SIM" state. When in the "No SIM" state, no further attempts at registration on any PLMN are made until the MS is switched off and on again, or a SIM is inserted. If performing GPRS attach, EPS attach for emergency bearer services, an initial registration for emergency services, or EPS attach for access to RLOS, the PLMN of the current serving cell is temporarily considered as the selected PLMN. In Automatic Network Selection mode, if the MS is in the "not updated" state with one or more suitable cells to camp on, and after the maximum allowed unsuccessful LR requests, the MS may continue (or start if not running) the user reselection procedure of clause 4.4.3.2.1. A multi-mode MS supporting 3GPP2 access technology may fall back to 3GPP2 mode if no SIM is inserted.

column1: Explain the process of Steering of Roaming when the MS receives a USAT REFRESH command qualifier of type "Steering of Roaming."
column2: When the MS receives a USAT REFRESH command qualifier of type "Steering of Roaming," the MS takes the following actions: a) Replaces the highest priority entries in the "Operator Controlled PLMN Selector with Access Technology" list stored in the ME with the list provided in the REFRESH command, if any, or replaces the SOR-CMCI in the ME with the SOR-CMCI provided in REFRESH command, if any, or both. b) Deletes the PLMNs identified by the list in the REFRESH command from the Forbidden PLMN list and from the Forbidden PLMNs for GPRS service list, if they are present in these lists. This includes any information stored in the SIM and the ME internal memory. c) Takes the new information into account in subsequent attempts to access a higher priority PLMN. d) Attempts to obtain service on a higher priority PLMN as specified in clause 4.4.3.3 by acting as if timer T that controls periodic attempts has expired.To avoid unnecessary signaling, the network operator should avoid repeatedly using steering of roaming for a particular MS.

column1: What does Table 1 in the provided text represent?
column2: Table 1 illustrates the Effect of LR (Location Registration) Outcomes on PLMN (Public Land Mobile Network) Registration. It includes information on different registration states and their corresponding outcomes.

column1: In which LR Task State is the Registration Status "Unsuccessful" when there is no IMSI (International Mobile Subscriber Identity)?
column2: In the "Idle, No IMSI" LR Task State, the Registration Status is "Unsuccessful" when there is no IMSI.

column1: What actions does an MS (Mobile Station) take in the LR Task State "Not updated" if the registration is unsuccessful?
column2: In the "Not updated" LR Task State, if the registration is unsuccessful, the MS will eventually attempt registration on another LA or TA of the same PLMN, or equivalent PLMN if available. Otherwise, it will enter either the Automatic Network Selection Mode procedure or follow the Manual Network Selection Mode procedure. If these processes do not result in registration, the MS will eventually enter the limited service state.

column1: According to Note 1, what is the significance of MSs having different registration statuses for GPRS and non-GPRS?
column2: According to Note 1, MSs capable of GPRS and non-GPRS services may have different registration statuses for GPRS and non-GPRS. This implies that the registration status may vary depending on the type of service being used.

column1: In Figure 1, what are the steps involved in the Overall Idle Mode process?
column2: The individual steps in the Overall Idle Mode process, as indicated in Figure 1, include setting the PLMN selection mode, presenting the list of available PLMNs to the user, user selection in manual PLMN selection mode, and various steps related to CSGs and cell selection.

column1: What does Figure 2a represent, and what is its significance?
column2: Figure 2a represents the PLMN Selection State diagram in automatic mode. It illustrates the states and transitions involved in the automatic PLMN selection process for a mobile station.

column1: According to Figure 3, what triggers the Location Registration Task State diagram?
column2: According to Figure 3, the Location Registration Task State diagram is triggered when the mobile station has selected a new cell, and the registration area has changed.

column1: What is the purpose of introducing PCS1900 with the regulatory mandate to allocate 3-digit MNC codes?
column2: The introduction of PCS1900 aims to allocate 3-digit MNC codes, requiring additional functionality to identify the HPLMN.

column1: According to the assumptions, how many decimal digits can an MNC code consist of?
column2: An MNC code can consist of either 2 or 3 decimal digits.

column1: What is the significance of the hexadecimal code "F" in the context of networks using a 2-digit MNC code?
column2: Networks using a 2-digit MNC code shall broadcast the hexadecimal code "F" in place of the 3rd digit.

column1: During the transition period in North America for PCS1900, what rule governs the storage of the 3rd digit of the SIM when a 2-digit MNC is broadcast?
column2: During the transition period, the 3rd digit of the SIM is stored as 0, following the 0 suffix rule.

column1: Explain the restriction regarding the broadcast of MNC codes within a single country (or area identified by a MCC) during the transition period.
column2: Within a single country, all networks must either broadcast a 2-digit MNC code or a 3-digit MNC code. A mixture of broadcast 2 and 3 digit MNC codes is not permitted.

column1: In the HPLMN matching criteria, what happens if the values of SIM-MCC and BCCH-MCC do not match?
column2: If the values of SIM-MCC and BCCH-MCC do not match, the HPLMN match fails.

column1: What is the condition for the number of digits used for SIM-MNC in relation to BCCH-MNC in the HPLMN matching criteria?
column2: If the MCC codes match, then the number of digits used for SIM-MNC must be the same as the number of digits used for BCCH-MNC.

column1: What does the HPLMN matching procedure involve when the 3rd digit of BCCH-MNC is Hex F?
column2: When the 3rd digit of BCCH-MNC is Hex F, the procedure proceeds to the next step (Step 4) in the matching criteria.

column1: Describe the matching procedure if the EHPLMN list is present and not empty during the HPLMN matching criteria.
column2: If the EHPLMN list is present and not empty, the matching procedure is done for all entries in the EHPLMN list until a match is found or all matches fail.

column1: In the logic flow diagram (Figure A.1), what happens if the EHPLMN list is present and empty?
column2: If the EHPLMN list is present and empty, the matching procedure is done for the MCC/MNC of the IMSI.

column1: What is the purpose of the control plane solution for steering of roaming in 5GS procedure in a PLMN?
column2: The purpose of the control plane solution for steering of roaming in 5GS procedure in a PLMN is to allow the HPLMN to update various parameters via NAS signaling, including the "Operator Controlled PLMN Selector with Access Technology" list, SOR-CMCI, SOR-SNPN-SI, and others.

column1: What criteria determine if a VPLMN and a PLMN are considered to be of the same country while an MS is roaming?
column2: The VPLMN and a PLMN are considered to be of the same country while an MS is roaming only if their MCC values identify the same country. Refer to clause 1.2 for the definition of the country.

column1: What information can the HPLMN update during and after registration in a VPLMN using the control plane solution for steering of roaming in 5GS?
column2: The HPLMN can update various information during and after registration in a VPLMN, including the "Operator Controlled PLMN Selector with Access Technology" list, SOR-CMCI, SOR-SNPN-SI, SOR-SNPN-SI-LS, SOR-SENSE, and slice-based PLMN selection information.

column1: What is the purpose of the SOR-CMCI in the context of steering of roaming in 5GS?
column2: The SOR-CMCI (Steering of Roaming Connected Mode Control Information) enables the HPLMN to control the timing of a UE in 5GS connected mode to move to idle mode to perform the steering of roaming. It is used to influence the UE's behavior during roaming.

column1: How does the UE handle the situation if the VPLMN alters or removes the steering of roaming information?
column2: If the UE detects that the VPLMN altered or removed the steering of roaming information, it considers the current VPLMN as the lowest priority PLMN and performs PLMN selection as defined in the annex.

column1: What is the significance of the list of "PLMNs where registration was aborted due to SOR" in the UE?
column2: The UE maintains a list of "PLMNs where registration was aborted due to SOR," and if the conditions are met, it performs PLMN selection with the current VPLMN considered as the lowest priority.

column1: How does the non-subscribed SNPN handle steering of roaming information received from the HPLMN or subscribed SNPN?
column2: The non-subscribed SNPN is mandated to transparently forward the steering of roaming information received from the HPLMN or subscribed SNPN to the UE. It also forwards the acknowledgment of successful reception of the information back to the HPLMN or subscribed SNPN.

column1: What is the purpose of the REGISTRATION REQUEST message sent by the UE to the VPLMN AMF?
column2: The REGISTRATION REQUEST message is sent by the UE to initiate initial registration, emergency registration, or registration procedures for mobility and periodic registration update to the VPLMN AMF.

column1: How does the VPLMN AMF handle the registration procedure upon receiving the REGISTRATION REQUEST message?
column2: The VPLMN AMF executes the registration procedure, including providing the registration type to the User Data Management (UDM) and obtaining subscription data if not available.

column1: When does the VPLMN AMF invoke the Nudm_SDM_Get service operation to the HPLMN UDM?
column2: The VPLMN AMF invokes Nudm_SDM_Get when it either doesn't have subscription data for the UE or when specific conditions related to the 5GS registration type are met.

column1: What actions does the HPLMN UDM take if the user subscription information indicates sending the steering of roaming information during initial registration in a VPLMN?
column2: The HPLMN UDM may provide the steering of roaming information to the UE based on operator policy. It can also send the list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations to the Service Provider Application Function (SP-AF) if supported.

column1: How does the SOR-AF respond to the HPLMN UDM's Nsoraf_SoR_Get request?
column2: The SOR-AF responds with either the list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations, SOR-CMCI, secured packet, or none of them based on operator-specific criteria.

column1: In which scenarios does the UE release the current N1 NAS signaling connection during steering of roaming?
column2: The UE releases the N1 NAS signaling connection when it needs to obtain service on a higher priority PLMN or based on specific conditions related to the steering of roaming information.

column1: What does the UE do if the security check is not successful after receiving the steering of roaming information during initial registration in a VPLMN?
column2: The UE may release the current N1 NAS signaling connection locally and attempt to obtain service on a higher priority PLMN or take other specified actions based on the scenario.

column1: What is the trigger for the procedure described in the text?
column2: The procedure is triggered when the HPLMN UDM supports obtaining a list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations and SOR-CMCI, if any, or a secured packet from the SOR-AF.

column1: How does the SOR-AF determine that the ME supports the SOR-CMCI?
column2: The SOR-AF can determine that the ME supports the SOR-CMCI if the Nsoraf_SoR_Info service operation has returned the "ME support of SOR-CMCI" indicator.

column1: What information can the secured packet obtained by the UDM include?
column2: The secured packet obtained by the UDM can include SOR-CMCI only if the "ME support of SOR-CMCI" indicator is stored for the UE and the USIM of the indicated SUPI supports SOR-CMCI.

column1: How does the UE handle a USAT REFRESH command qualifier of type "Steering of Roaming"?
column2: Depending on whether a SOR-CMCI is included or the UE is configured with the SOR-CMCI, the UE performs specific actions as outlined in the procedure for steering of roaming.

column1: When does the UE release the current N1 NAS signalling connection?
column2: The UE releases the current N1 NAS signalling connection locally and attempts to obtain service on a higher priority PLMN as specified in clause 4.4.3.3 when certain conditions are met, such as a successful security check or when there are no ongoing PDU sessions or services.

column1: What does the AMF include in the DL NAS TRANSPORT message sent to the UE?
column2: The AMF includes in the DL NAS TRANSPORT message the steering of roaming information received from the UDM.

column1: How does the HPLMN UDM handle the "ME support of SOR-CMCI" indicator in the SOR transparent container?
column2: Depending on the value of the "ME support of SOR-CMCI" indicator in the SOR transparent container, the HPLMN UDM either stores or deletes the indicator.

column1: What does the HPLMN UDM inform the SOR-AF about in step 6?
column2: The HPLMN UDM informs the SOR-AF about the successful delivery of the list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations, SOR-CMCI, if any, or of the secured packet to the UE, including certain indicators if stored.

column1: In which scenario does the UE wait before attempting to obtain service on a higher priority PLMN?
column2: If the selected PLMN is a VPLMN and the UE encounters security check failure of SOR information in DL NAS TRANSPORT message while in manual mode, upon switching to automatic network selection mode, the UE waits before attempting to obtain service on a higher priority PLMN.

column1: What is the purpose of the Nudm_ParameterProvision_Update request in step 1?
column2: The Nudm_ParameterProvision_Update request is sent from the SOR-AF to the HPLMN UDM to trigger the update of the UE with the new list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations, SOR-CMCI, if any, and the "Store SOR-CMCI in ME" indicator, if any, or a secured packet for a UE identified by SUPI.

column1: What is SOR-CMCI and how is it configured in the UE?
column2: SOR-CMCI, Steering of Roaming Control and Mobility Control Information, is configured in the UE by the HPLMN or subscribed SNPN based on operator policy. It controls the timing of the UE entering idle mode and performing higher priority PLMN/access technology or SNPN selection.

column1: How is the SOR-CMCI stored in the UE, and what happens if the security check fails during the steering of roaming procedure?
column2: The SOR-CMCI can be configured and stored in the UE by the HPLMN or subscribed SNPN. If the security check fails during the steering of roaming procedure, the UE uses the stored SOR-CMCI from non-volatile memory if available; otherwise, it uses the SOR-CMCI from the USIM.

column1: What parameters make up the SOR-CMCI rule, and how many SOR-CMCI rules can the UE handle for different criteria?
column2: Each SOR-CMCI rule consists of a criterion (PDU session attribute type, service type, SOR security check, or match all type) and a Tsor-cm timer value. The UE can handle up to 4 SOR-CMCI rules for PDU session attribute type, 4 for service type, and 6 for other criteria.

column1: How does the UE handle SOR-CMCI during the SOR procedure, and what happens if there are multiple applicable Tsor-cm timers?
column2: During the SOR procedure, the UE starts Tsor-cm timers based on the matching criteria. If multiple Tsor-cm timers are applicable for different ongoing PDU sessions or services, all applicable timers are started. Further handling is described in clause C.4.2.

column1: What exemptions does the UE have from releasing established PDU sessions based on SOR-CMCI, and when does it consider the current PLMN or SNPN as not the lowest priority?
column2: The UE is exempt from releasing established PDU sessions for emergency services. If configured with high priority access, all services and related PDU sessions are exempt. The current PLMN or SNPN is not considered the lowest priority during successful security checks.

column1: How does the UE apply SOR-CMCI during the SOR procedure, and what happens if it enters idle mode or 5GMM-CONNECTED mode while Tsor-cm timers are running?
column2: The UE applies SOR-CMCI during the SOR procedure by starting Tsor-cm timers based on matching criteria. If it enters idle mode or 5GMM-CONNECTED mode while Tsor-cm timers are running, it stops the timers. If the UE is in automatic network selection mode, it attempts to obtain service on a higher priority PLMN or SNPN.

column1: What is the stage-2 flow for providing the UE with SOR-CMCI after registration, and how is the SOR-CMCI sent to the UE from the SOR-AF?
column2: The stage-2 flow involves triggering the update of the UE with SOR-CMCI, which can be sent in plain text or secured packet. The SOR-CMCI is sent by the SOR-AF to the UDM, and if the UE supports SOR-CMCI, it is included in the DL NAS TRANSPORT message to the UE.

column1: What initiates the registration procedure for the UE in the described stage-2 flow for steering in SNPN during registration?
column2: The registration procedure for the UE is initiated by the UE, which sends a REGISTRATION REQUEST message to the AMF indicating "initial registration," "emergency registration," or "mobility registration updating" through the 5GS registration type IE.

column1: What role does the AMF play upon receiving the REGISTRATION REQUEST message from the UE?
column2: Upon receiving the REGISTRATION REQUEST message, the AMF executes the registration procedure, providing the registration type to the UDM. Depending on the registration type, the UDM may delete stored indicators related to SOR-CMCI and SOR-SNPN-SI-LS.

column1: Under what conditions does the AMF request SOR information from the UDM during the registration procedure?
column2: The AMF requests SOR information from the UDM if it does not have subscription data for the UE or if the registration type indicates "initial registration" or "emergency registration" with specific conditions related to SOR information retrieval.

column1: How does the UDM handle providing SOR-SNPN-SI during the registration in a non-subscribed SNPN?
column2: The UDM checks user subscription information to determine whether to provide SOR-SNPN-SI during the registration in a non-subscribed SNPN. If the condition is met, the UDM provides the information; otherwise, it may provide SOR-SNPN-SI based on policies.

column1: What steps are involved in the communication between the UDM and SOR-AF to retrieve SOR-SNPN-SI during registration?
column2: The UDM sends an Nsoraf_SoR_Get request to the SOR-AF, including parameters like SNPN identity and UE SUPI. The SOR-AF responds with an Nsoraf_SoR_Get response, containing SOR-SNPN-SI and related indicators.

column1: How does the UE handle the received steering of roaming information during the registration procedure?
column2: If the UE receives steering of roaming information and the security check is successful, it may acknowledge the information. The UE may replace preferred SNPNs, GINs, or perform SNPN selection based on the received information.

column1: In which situations does the UE attempt to obtain service on a higher priority SNPN after the registration procedure?
column2: The UE attempts to obtain service on a higher priority SNPN after the registration procedure if it determines a higher priority SNPN based on available SNPNs, and it is in automatic network selection mode.

column1: What actions does the UE take if the security check of the received steering of roaming information fails during registration?
column2: If the security check fails, the UE may release the current N1 NAS signaling connection locally and attempt to obtain service on a higher priority SNPN. The specific actions depend on the UE's configuration and mode of operation.

column1: What is the purpose of the Stage-2 flow for steering of UE in SNPN?
column2: The purpose is to manage the steering of UE in an SNPN after registration.

column1: Where is the AMF located in this scenario?
column2: The AMF is located in the selected SNPN.

column1: In which locations can the UE be registered?
column2: The UE can be registered on either the subscribed SNPN or a non-subscribed SNPN.

column1: What role does the UDM play in this process?
column2: The UDM is responsible for managing user data and is located in the HPLMN or subscribed SNPN.

column1: What does figure C.6.1 represent in the described stage-2 flow?
column2: Figure C.6.1 represents the indicated stage-2 flow for the steering of UE in SNPN after registration.

column1: When is the procedure triggered?
column2: The procedure is triggered if certain conditions related to UDM support and information availability from the AF are met.

column1: Can you explain the significance of the selected SNPN in the described scenario?
column2: The selected SNPN is crucial as the AMF is located in it, and the UE is registered on it.

column1: How is the UE's location information obtained before providing certain information to the UDM?
column2: The UE's location information can be obtained by triggering the unified location service exposure procedure or by requesting it from other application functions.

column1: What actions does the UE take if the security check on the received steering of roaming information is successful?
column2: If successful, the UE may replace its credentials holder controlled prioritized lists based on the received information.

column1: What happens if the security check is not successful, and the UE is in automatic network selection mode?
column2: In such cases, the UE may wait or release the current N1 NAS signaling connection based on certain conditions.

column1: What is the purpose of the Nudm_ParameterProvision_Update request in the described procedure?
column2: The Nudm_ParameterProvision_Update request is sent from the SOR-AF to the UDM to trigger the update of the UE with the SOR-SNPN-SI or SOR-SNPN-SI-LS.

column1: How does the UDM notify the AMF about changes in the user profile in step 2 of the procedure?
column2: The UDM notifies the AMF by invoking the Nudm_SDM_Notification service operation, including steering of roaming information to be delivered to the UE.

column1: What information does the DL NAS TRANSPORT message sent by the AMF to the UE contain?
column2: The DL NAS TRANSPORT message includes the steering of roaming information received from the UDM.

column1: What actions does the UE take upon a successful security check of the received steering of roaming information in step 4a?
column2: The UE updates its prioritized lists for SNPNs, GINs, and access for localized services in SNPN. It also acknowledges the successful security check if requested by the UDM.

column1: In which scenario does the UE wait before attempting to obtain service on a higher priority PLMN in step 4b?
column2: The UE waits if it is in the automatic network selection mode, has a stored SOR-CMCI, and there are ongoing PDU sessions or services.

column1: How does the AMF inform the UDM about the successful delivery of the steering of roaming information in step 5?
column2: The AMF uses the Nudm_SDM_Info service operation to provide the received SOR transparent container to the UDM.

column1: What indicators does the UDM store related to the UE's support for steering of roaming information features in step 5?
column2: The UDM stores the "ME support of SOR-SNPN-SI" indicator. If the "ME support of SOR-SNPN-SI-LS" indicator is set to "supported," it is also stored; otherwise, it is deleted.

column1: What happens if the selected PLMN is a VPLMN, and the UE encounters a security check failure in manual mode?
column2: The UE waits until it moves to idle mode or 5GMM-CONNECTED mode with RRC inactive indication before attempting to obtain service on a higher priority PLMN.

column1: What triggers the procedure for providing a User Equipment (UE) with a list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations in an SNPN after registration?
column2: The procedure is triggered based on Home Public Land Mobile Network (HPLMN) policy, specifically when the HPLMN supports sending the list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations to the UE in plain text or secured packet after the UE is registered to a non-subscribed SNPN.
column3: The document provides an extensive glossary of terms related to mobile communication systems, particularly focusing on network selection procedures and related functionalities. It covers a wide range of acronyms and concepts, such as Extended Access Barring (EAB), Extended Coverage in GSM for Internet of Things (EC-GSM-IoT), Home PLMN, Steering of Roaming (SOR), Localised Service Area (LSA), and many others. The definitions include details on network modes, registration procedures, and specialized services. The document aims to establish a standardized understanding of terminology within the context of mobile communication, ensuring clarity and consistency in the implementation and operation of these systems. Additionally, it provides an overview of the tasks performed by the Core network protocols of a Mobile Station (MS) during idle mode, where the MS is switched on but lacks a dedicated channel. It covers functions applicable to GPRS MS as long as no dedicated channel is allocated. The conditions for idle mode functions in various network states (UTRA RRC connected mode, E-UTRAN, NG-RAN) are specified. The document defines PLMN selection for a multi-mode MS supporting 3GPP and 3GPP2 systems, outlining common PLMN selection logic. Procedures for using CSG and CAG cells, SNPN selection, and implementation of idle mode requirements from 3GPP TS 22 series are detailed. Additionally, it addresses steering of roaming in 5GS, SNPN access mode, and control plane solutions. The document provides references to relevant specifications and clarifies abbreviations and definitions related to idle mode operations in mobile networks.

column1: What are the conditions under which the User Equipment (UE) acknowledges successful security checks during the steering of roaming information process?
column2: If the security check on the received steering of roaming information is successful, the UE acknowledges by either uploading a secured packet to the Universal Subscriber Identity Module (USIM) or replacing the highest priority entries in the "Operator Controlled PLMN Selector with Access Technology" list and providing an acknowledgment to the serving Access and Mobility Function (AMF). The acknowledgment includes setting the "ME support of SOR-SNPN-SI" indicator to "supported" if requested by the User Data Management (UDM).

column1: How does the User Equipment (UE) handle a security check failure of steering of roaming information in automatic network selection mode?
column2: If the security check fails and the UE is in automatic network selection mode, the UE takes different actions depending on whether it has a stored System Operator's Roaming Control-Mobility Control Indicator (SOR-CMCI). If a SOR-CMCI is present, the current Selected Next Public Land Mobile Network (SNPN) is considered the lowest priority, and specific actions are taken. If no SOR-CMCI is stored, the UE waits until it moves to idle mode or 5GMM-CONNECTED mode with Radio Resource Control (RRC) inactive indication before attempting to obtain service on a higher priority SNPN.

column1: How is the acknowledgment of successful delivery of the steering of roaming information communicated between the User Data Management (UDM) and the System Operator's Roaming Application Function (SOR-AF)?
column2: The UDM informs the SOR-AF about the successful delivery of the steering of roaming information using the Nsoraf_SoR_Info message. This message includes the Subscriber Permanent Identifier (SUPI) of the UE, an indication of successful delivery, and the "ME support of SOR-SNPN-SI" indicator. The acknowledgment is sent if the HPLMN policy for the SOR-AF invocation is present, and the HPLMN UDM received and verified the UE acknowledgment during the process.

column1: What corrective actions does the User Equipment (UE) take in case of a security check failure of System Operator's Roaming (SOR) information during automatic network selection mode?
column2: If the security check fails and the UE is in automatic network selection mode, corrective actions depend on whether the UE has a stored System Operator's Roaming Control-Mobility Control Indicator (SOR-CMCI). If a SOR-CMCI is present and there are ongoing PDU sessions or services, the current SNPN is considered the lowest priority, and specific actions are taken. If there are no ongoing PDU sessions or services, the UE releases the current NAS signaling connection locally and attempts to obtain service on a higher priority SNPN. If the UE does not have a SOR-CMCI stored, similar actions are taken with the exception that the UE waits until it moves to idle mode or 5GMM-CONNECTED mode with RRC inactive indication before attempting to obtain service on a higher priority SNPN.

column1: What does the present document outline regarding the Core network protocols of a Mobile Station (MS) in idle mode?
column2: The present document provides an overview of the tasks performed by the Core network protocols of an MS in idle mode, where it is switched on but typically not assigned a dedicated channel. It also describes the corresponding network functions.

column1: Under what conditions are the idle mode functions performed by an MS in the UTRA RRC connected mode states?
column2: The conditions for idle mode functions in the UTRA RRC connected mode states are specified in 3GPP TS 25.331 [33].

column1: What does the document specify about PLMN selection for a multi-mode MS supporting both 3GPP and 3GPP2 systems?
column2: The document defines PLMN selection for a multi-mode MS supporting both 3GPP and 3GPP2 systems, including common PLMN selection logic covering PLMNs available in 3GPP2 systems.

column1: In the context of SNPN selection, what does the present document specify?
column2: The present document specifies SNPN selection, outlining procedures related to the selection of SNPNs.

column1: According to the document, what is the purpose of Annex C and to which entities in the 5GS does it apply?
column2: Annex C describes the procedures for the control plane solution of steering of roaming in 5GS and is applicable to the MS, the AMF, the UDM, and the SOR-AF.

column1: Does the present document consider GERAN Iu mode?
column2: No, the present document explicitly states that it does not consider GERAN Iu mode.

column1: What is the significance of the term "Allowable PLMN/access technology combination" for an MS operating in MS operation mode A or B?
column2: For an MS operating in MS operation mode A or B, it refers to a combination where the PLMN is allowable, and the specific access technology supports non-GPRS services or the PLMN is not forbidden, and the access technology supports only GPRS services.

column1: How is an "Acceptable Cell" defined, and what criteria must it satisfy for an MS?
column2: An Acceptable Cell is a cell where the MS may camp on to make emergency calls or access RLOS. It must satisfy criteria defined in various specifications depending on the mode, such as A/Gb mode, Iu mode, S1 mode, and NR access in N1 mode.

column1: What does "Discontinuous coverage" refer to in the context of satellite E-UTRAN access?
column2: Discontinuous coverage is a deployment option for satellite E-UTRAN access, involving shorter periods of coverage followed by longer coverage gaps, during which the access stratum may be deactivated.

column1: How is an "Allowable SNPN" defined for an MS operating in SNPN access mode?
column2: For an MS operating in SNPN access mode, an Allowable SNPN is one that is not permanently or temporarily forbidden, associated with the selected entry of the "list of subscriber data" or the selected PLMN subscription.

column1: What is Extended Access Barring (EAB)?
column2: Extended Access Barring (EAB) is defined in 3GPP TS 22.011 [9].

column1: What is the purpose of the Equivalent HPLMN list?
column2: The Equivalent HPLMN list allows provision for multiple HPLMN codes. PLMN codes in this list replace the HPLMN code derived from the IMSI for PLMN selection purposes.

column1: Define Generic Access Network (GAN) mode.
column2: GAN mode is defined in 3GPP TS 43.318 [35A].

column1: When does a mobile station attempt to find a cell supporting EC-GSM-IoT disregard the high-quality signal limit?
column2: When attempting to find a cell supporting EC-GSM-IoT, the high-quality signal limit is disregarded. Any cell supporting EC-GSM-IoT is considered received with a high-quality signal.

column1: What is the definition of Home PLMN?
column2: Home PLMN refers to a PLMN where the MCC and MNC of the PLMN identity match the MCC and MNC of the IMSI. Matching criteria are defined in Annex A.

column1: Explain the meaning of Limited Service State.
column2: Limited Service State is covered in clause 3.5. It refers to a specific state defined in the document.

column1: What is Steering of Roaming (SOR)?
column2: Steering of Roaming (SOR) is a technique where a roaming UE is encouraged to roam to a preferred roamed-to-network indicated by the HPLMN.

column1: Define the term Secured packet in the context of this specification.
