column2: In this specification, a secured packet contains one or more of the following: list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations, SOR-CMCI, and slice-based PLMN selection information, encapsulated with a security mechanism as described in 3GPP TS 31.115 [67].

column1: Explain the concept of Steering of Roaming information.
column2: Steering of Roaming information consists of indicators and one of the following: list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations, secured packet, HPLMN indication of no change needed, or SNPN indication of no change needed.

column1: What is the purpose of the Steering of Roaming SNPN selection information (SOR-SNPN-SI)?
column2: SOR-SNPN-SI provides provisioning information for SNPN selection, including a credentials holder-controlled prioritized list of preferred SNPNs and/or GINs.

column1: What is the purpose of camping on a cell in idle mode for a mobile station (MS)?
column2: The purpose of camping on a cell in idle mode for an MS is fourfold: a) To enable the MS to receive system information from the selected Public Land Mobile Network (PLMN) or Stand-Alone Non-Public Network (SNPN). b) If the MS wishes to initiate a call, it can access the network on the control channel of the camped cell. c) When the PLMN or SNPN receives a call for the MS, it sends a "paging" message on control channels within the registration area, allowing the MS to respond on the tuned control channel. d) It enables the MS to receive cell broadcast messages.

column1: What are the main tasks involved in the idle mode operation of a mobile station (MS)?
column2: The idle mode tasks for an MS can be subdivided into the following processes: PLMN selection SNPN selection (N1 mode only) CSG selection (Iu mode and S1 mode only) Cell selection and reselection Location registration CTS fixed part selection (A/Gb mode only) CAG selection (N1 mode only)

column1: How does the MS handle network rejections and forbidden areas during PLMN selection?
column2: During PLMN selection, if the MS receives a rejection message or identifies forbidden areas, it takes specific actions: Forbidden location areas are stored to prevent repeated attempts for roaming service. PLMNs not allowed in certain areas are added to lists, which are periodically deleted or cleared upon MS shutdown or SIM removal. In automatic PLMN selection mode, if a forbidden PLMN is detected, the MS considers it as a candidate only if the current MS location is known, and specific timers manage the removal of entries from forbidden lists.

column1: What actions does the MS take if it receives a reject message with cause value #15 during PLMN selection in A/Gb mode or Iu mode?
column2: Depending on the mode in which the message is received, the MS takes the following actions: A/Gb mode or Iu mode: The location area or tracking area causing the rejection is added to the list of "forbidden location areas for roaming" or "forbidden tracking areas for roaming," respectively. The MS then searches for a suitable cell within the same PLMN but belonging to an area not on the forbidden list.

column1: How does the MS handle the disabling of E-UTRA capability and maintain a list of PLMNs where voice service was not possible in E-UTRAN?
column2: If the MS receives a reject message with 5GMM cause #27 "N1 mode not allowed," the MS takes the following actions: Adds the PLMN to the list of "PLMNs where N1 mode is not allowed for 3GPP access" and starts a timer. In automatic PLMN selection, the MS avoids considering PLMNs on this list as candidates for NG-RAN access technology, unless no other PLMN is available. The MS deletes stored information on such PLMNs when switched off, the USIM is removed, or the timer expires.

column1: What are the two modes of CSG selection mentioned in the text?
column2: The two modes of CSG selection are Automatic mode and Manual mode.

column1: How is the Allowed CSG list updated when entries are removed from the Operator CSG list?
column2: The Allowed CSG list is updated in the same operation when one or more entries are removed from the Operator CSG list.

column1: How does the MS behave in the Automatic mode of CSG selection?
column2: In Automatic mode, the MS camps on a cell in the selected PLMN only if the cell is either not a CSG cell or it is a CSG cell with a CSG identity in the Allowed CSG list or Operator CSG list.

column1: What is the permitted CSG list, and how is it formed?
column2: The permitted CSG list is a combination of the Operator CSG list and the Allowed CSG list. It is provided to the AS by NAS, and duplicates can be removed when combining these lists.

column1: In CSG manual mode selection, what determines the list of available CSGs provided to the user?
column2: The list of available CSGs provided to the user is either not restricted by the Allowed CSG list and Operator CSG List stored in the MS, or it is restricted to entries in the Operator CSG List only, based on configuration by the HPLMN.

column1: What are the two modes of CSG selection?
column2: The two modes of CSG selection are Automatic mode and Manual mode.

column1: How does the MS behave in the Automatic mode of CSG selection?
column2: In Automatic mode, the MS camps on a cell in the selected PLMN if the cell is not a CSG cell or is a CSG cell with a CSG identity in the Allowed CSG list or Operator CSG List.

column1: What triggers PLMN selection for ProSe communications in the MS?
column2: PLMN selection for ProSe communications is triggered if the MS supports ProSe communications and needs to perform PLMN selection as specified in 3GPP TS 24.334 [51] or 3GPP TS 24.554 [80].

column1: How does the MS choose an allowable PLMN for ProSe communications?
column2: The MS chooses an allowable PLMN for ProSe communications among the PLMNs advertised by the E-UTRA cell or NR cell operating in the radio resources provisioned for ProSe communications.

column1: What does the MS do if the registration fails during PLMN selection for ProSe communications?
column2: If the registration fails during PLMN selection for ProSe communications, the MS may perform ProSe communications on the selected PLMN in limited service state, return to the stored duplicate PLMN selection mode, or perform the PLMN selection procedure again.

column1: What are the conditions for selecting a PLMN for V2X communication over PC5?
column2: The conditions for selecting a PLMN for V2X communication over PC5 include providing radio resources for V2X communication, being in the list of authorized PLMNs, and not being in the list of "PLMNs with E-UTRAN not allowed."

column1: How does the MS handle a registration failure during PLMN selection for V2X communication?
column2: If the registration fails during PLMN selection for V2X communication, the MS may perform V2X communication on the selected PLMN in limited service state, return to the stored duplicate PLMN selection mode, or perform the PLMN selection procedure again.

column1: What are the steps for PLMN selection triggered by A2X communication over PC5?
column2: The steps for PLMN selection triggered by A2X communication over PC5 include storing duplicate values, entering Automatic mode, choosing an allowable PLMN, handling registration failures, and performing A2X communication in limited service state.

column1: How does the MS prevent potential ping-pong between the RPLMN and the PLMN selected for A2X communication?
column2: The solution to prevent potential ping-pong between the RPLMN and the PLMN selected for A2X communication is MS implementation specific.

column1: What happens when an MS with "regionally restricted service" attempts to camp on a cell for which it does not have service entitlement?
column2: If an MS with "regionally restricted service" attempts to camp on a cell without service entitlement, it receives an LR response with cause value #12. The MS then takes actions based on the received message and its operational mode.

column1: How does the MS handle LR requests in A/Gb mode or Iu mode when a forbidden LA is encountered?
column2: In A/Gb mode or Iu mode, if the LR request encounters a forbidden LA, the MS stores the forbidden LA identity in a list and enters the limited service state. The list is periodically deleted or upon MS shutdown or SIM removal.

column1: In S1-mode, what actions does the MS take when a forbidden TA is encountered during LR request for regional provision of service?
column2: In S1-mode, if a forbidden TA is encountered during LR request for regional provision of service, the MS stores the forbidden TA identity in a list, enters the limited service state, and periodically deletes the list or upon MS shutdown or SIM removal.

column1: What conditions lead to the MS entering the limited service state?
column2: The MS enters the limited service state in various conditions, including failure to find a suitable cell, absence of a valid SIM or "list of subscriber data," LR failures, and specific responses indicating service restrictions.

column1: How does the MS handle network access restriction based on Emergency Access Barring (EAB)?
column2: The MS, configured for EAB, follows the EAB mechanism when network access is restricted. It can be configured for EAB in the USIM or ME and ignores EAB in case of emergency calls.

column1: What restrictions apply to MSs with forbidden LA or TA for regional provision of service?
column2: MSs are not allowed to initiate CM connections or request GPRS/5GS services when camped on a cell with forbidden LA or TA for regional provision of service. However, they may respond to paging.

column1: Under what circumstances does the MS search for available and allowable PLMNs in the limited service state?
column2: In the limited service state, the MS searches for available and allowable PLMNs when a valid SIM is present and either a suitable cell is found or a manual network reselection is performed.

column1: How does the MS handle SNPN access operation mode over 3GPP access during emergency situations?
column2: In emergency situations, the MS may operate in SNPN access operation mode over 3GPP access to camp on a cell supporting emergency services. After an emergency call, it may revert to normal PLMN selection.

column1: What are the conditions for initiating ProSe communications or V2X communication over PC5 in limited service state?
column2: ProSe communications or V2X communication over PC5 can be initiated in the limited service state due to specific LR failure conditions, such as failure to find a suitable cell or restricted network access.

column1: How does the MS handle PLMN selection for disaster roaming in the limited service state?
column2: If the MS selected a PLMN for disaster roaming, it stays in the limited service state if the timer precluding registration is running. It registers for emergency services if necessary and conditions permit.

column1: What criteria does the CTS MS use to attach to a CTS fixed part when operating in CTS mode or automatic mode with CTS preferred?
column2: The CTS MS uses the criteria C1_CTS and C2_CTS to attach to a CTS fixed part. Specifically, the C1_CTS criterion should be greater than zero for attachment, and the C2_CTS criterion falling below zero indicates that the CTS MS is no longer under CTS coverage.

column1: How is NAS behavior configured, and what parameters are used for configuration in the context of operator preferences?
column2: NAS behavior is configured using parameters in the USIM or the ME, and the configuration can be operator-specific. Parameters available in both the USIM and the ME are configurable, with precedence specified in 3GPP TS 31.102 [40] clause 5.2.29.

column1: In N1 mode, under what conditions can the MS be provisioned by the network with a "CAG information list," and what information does this list contain?
column2: In N1 mode, the MS may be provisioned by the network with a "CAG information list" if it supports CAG. This list includes entries with PLMN ID, an "Allowed CAG list" containing CAG-IDs, and an optional indication of whether the MS is only allowed to access 5GS via CAG cells.

column1: What is the significance of the "CAG information list" in the context of PLMN registration, and how does the MS handle it when registered to HPLMN or EHPLMN?
column2: The "CAG information list" is used during PLMN registration. When the MS is registered to a PLMN other than the HPLMN or EHPLMN, the HPLMN sends a "CAG information list" related to the serving PLMN only. When registered to the HPLMN or EHPLMN, the HPLMN or EHPLMN can send CAG subscription information related to any PLMN in the list. The MS may also be pre-configured with a "CAG information list" stored in the USIM.

column1: What are the two modes for SNPN selection, and how does the MS operate in each mode?
column2: The two modes for SNPN selection are Automatic SNPN selection mode and Manual SNPN selection mode. In Automatic mode, the MS automatically selects an SNPN based on configured parameters, while in Manual mode, the selection is performed manually by the user or the network.

column1: What is Minimization of Service Interruption (MINT), and when is it applicable?
column2: MINT (Minimization of Service Interruption) is a feature that the MS may support. It is not applicable in SNPNs. MINT aims to reduce service interruptions, especially in disaster scenarios, by allowing the MS to be provisioned with disaster roaming-related information.

column1: Under what conditions may the MS attempt to access a PLMN on a CAG cell for disaster roaming services, and what information is needed for disaster roaming configuration?
column2: The MS may attempt to access a PLMN on a CAG cell for disaster roaming services if the CAG-ID is authorized based on the "Allowed CAG list" in the "CAG information list." Disaster roaming configuration includes parameters such as disaster roaming wait range, disaster return wait range, and lists of PLMNs for disaster conditions.

column1: What conditions trigger the storage of disaster-related information from the USIM into the ME, and what happens if the MS does not have an indication of whether disaster roaming is enabled?
column2: The conditions triggering storage include USIM insertion, updates through USAT REFRESH commands, and scenarios where the information in the USIM does not match that stored in the ME. If the MS does not have an indication of whether disaster roaming is enabled, or if it is set to "Disaster roaming is disabled," the MS does not perform disaster roaming.

column1: Describe the process the MS follows upon selecting a PLMN for disaster roaming, including the role of the disaster roaming wait range and the associated timer.
column2: Upon selecting a PLMN for disaster roaming, the MS generates a random number within the disaster roaming wait range and starts a timer. During the timer period, the MS does not initiate registration, except for emergency services. After the timer expires, the MS may initiate registration if not engaged in an emergency PDU session. The process helps minimize service interruptions during disaster conditions.

column1: What actions does the MS take upon determining the end of a disaster condition and selecting a PLMN previously associated with a disaster condition?
column2: Upon determining the end of a disaster condition and selecting a PLMN previously associated with a disaster condition, the MS generates a random number within the disaster return wait range and starts a timer. Similar to the disaster roaming scenario, during the timer period, the MS refrains from initiating registration, except for emergency services. After the timer expires, the MS may initiate registration if not engaged in an emergency PDU session.

column1: Under what conditions does Signal Level Enhanced Network Selection apply, and what are the prerequisites for an MS to use this feature in the context of NB-IoT, GERAN EC-GSM-IoT, and Category M1 or M2 of E-UTRA?
column2: Signal Level Enhanced Network Selection applies to NB-IoT, GERAN EC-GSM-IoT, and Category M1 or M2 of E-UTRA. For an MS to use this feature, the following conditions must be fulfilled: The MS is in automatic PLMN selection mode. The MS supports the "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology" specified in 3GPP TS 22.011 [19]. The MS is configured to use signal level enhanced network selection as specified in 3GPP TS 24.368 [50]. The MS is configured to use signal level enhanced network selection as specified in 3GPP TS 31.102 [40]. The "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology" is configured in the USIM as specified in 3GPP TS 31.102 [40].

column1: What is the intended usage of the "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology," and for which type of devices is it expected to be supported?
column2: The "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology" is intended for IoT stationary devices (as per 3GPP TS 22.011 [19]). It is not expected to be supported by non-IoT devices.

column1: What information does the "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology" stored in the USIM contain, and how is it specific to a certain access technology?
column2: This information is specific to a certain access technology and, when applicable, applies to all allowable PLMNs with the corresponding access technology combination.

column1: How can the HPLMN update the "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology," and how does the MS use the updated information for subsequent PLMN selections?
column2: The HPLMN can update the "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology" via steering of roaming information. When the ME receives a USAT REFRESH command indicating that the "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology" stored in the USIM has been updated, an MS which applies Signal Level Enhanced Network Selection (SENSE) shall use the updated information provided by the HPLMN for subsequent PLMN selections.

column1: In addition to the USIM, how else can the "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology" be received by the MS, and what mechanism is involved?
column2: The "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology" can also be received from the HPLMN over the control plane steering of roaming mechanism. This mechanism allows the HPLMN to provide updated information directly to the MS over the control plane.

column1: What is the overall goal of the idle mode processes?
column2: The goal of the idle mode processes is to ensure that the registered PLMN is the selected PLMN and that the registered SNPN is the selected SNPN.

column1: Describe the relationship between PLMN selection and SNPN selection processes.
column2: Except for SNPN selection, the processes are illustrated in figure 1 in clause 5, and an event in one process may trigger a change in another process.

column1: In the PLMN selection process, what are the possible states in automatic mode?
column2: The possible states include Trying RPLMN, On PLMN, Trying PLMN, Wait for PLMNs to appear, HPLMN search in progress, and No SIM.

column1: Provide examples of LR reject causes that lead to the Idle state "Roaming not allowed."
column2: LR reject causes include PLMN not allowed, Location area not allowed, Tracking area not allowed, Roaming not allowed in this location area, Roaming not allowed in this tracking area, GPRS services not allowed in this PLMN, No suitable cells in location area, No suitable cells in tracking area, and Not authorized for this CSG.

column1: What is the purpose of the "Equivalent PLMNs" list stored by the Mobile Equipment?
column2: The "Equivalent PLMNs" list consists of PLMNs regarded as equivalent for PLMN selection, cell selection/re-selection, and handover. It is replaced or deleted during various network procedures.

column1: How does the MS select a PLMN at switch-on or recovery from lack of coverage?
column2: The MS selects the registered PLMN or equivalent PLMN (if available) using all access technologies, considering signal quality or operator-controlled signal thresholds stored in the USIM.

column1: What exceptions exist for the MS in automatic network selection mode during PLMN search?
column2: Exceptions include the option to register to an EHPLMN and not return to the registered PLMN, and the option to consider a list of "PLMNs where registration was aborted due to SOR" as lowest priority.

column1: When is the PLMN selection mode used at switch-on if the optional user preferred PLMN selection mode is provided?
column2: At switch-on, the user preferred PLMN selection mode is used if provided; otherwise, the MS uses the PLMN selection mode that was used before switching off.

column1: What is the purpose of the "HPLMN Selector with Access Technology" data file?
column2: The data file is used by the MS to get HPLMN access technologies related to the HPLMN code in the IMSI if the EHPLMN list is not present or is empty.

column1: In which cases does the MS ignore the RPLMN and its equivalent PLMN at switch-on?
column2: The MS ignores the RPLMN and its equivalent PLMN at switch-on if the RPLMN is a PLMN with disaster roaming services, and the cell does not broadcast disaster-related indications or a list of PLMNs with disaster conditions.

column1: What is the order of preference for PLMN/access technology combinations during automatic network selection mode?
column2: HPLMN (or highest priority EHPLMN if available) User Controlled PLMN Selector with Access Technology data file in the SIM Operator Controlled PLMN Selector with Access Technology data file in the SIM or stored in the ME PLMN/access technology combinations with received high-quality signal (in random order) PLMN/access technology combinations in order of decreasing signal quality PLMN/NG-RAN combinations for forbidden PLMNs with disaster condition indication (based on specific conditions) PLMN/NG-RAN combinations for other forbidden PLMNs with disaster condition indication (in random order)

column1: How should an MS handle PLMN selection in the absence of access technology information storage in the SIM during automatic network selection mode?
column2: In the absence of access technology information storage (User Controlled and Operator Controlled PLMN Selector with Access Technology data files) in the SIM during automatic network selection mode, an MS should use the "PLMN Selector" data file. For each PLMN in the "PLMN Selector" data file, the MS should search for all access technologies it is capable of, and the priority ordering among the access technologies is implementation dependent.

column1: What are the requirements for PLMN selection in the presence of voice capability during automatic network selection mode?
column2: The requirements for PLMN selection in the presence of voice capability during automatic network selection mode include: An MS with voice capability shall ignore PLMNs for which the MS has identified at least one GSM COMPACT. In A/Gb mode or GSM COMPACT, an MS with voice capability shall not search for CPBCCH carriers. The MS should limit its search for PLMNs in User Controlled or Operator Controlled selector lists for the specified access technology.The MS shall not consider PLMNs where voice service was not possible as PLMN selection candidates, unless no other allowed PLMN is available.

column1: How does an MS determine the MS determined PLMN with disaster condition during automatic network selection mode?
column2: The MS determines the MS determined PLMN with disaster condition during automatic network selection mode based on the following conditions:If the MS's RPLMN is included in any "list of one or more PLMN(s) with disaster condition for which disaster roaming services are offered by the available PLMN" broadcast by any NG-RAN cell and is allowable. If the MS's RPLMN is not included in any such list or the MS's RPLMN is not allowable, the MS determines the MS determined PLMN with disaster condition from allowable PLMNs in a specific order, including HPLMN or the highest priority EHPLMN.

column1: Under what conditions does an MS perform network selection for disaster roaming services during automatic network selection mode?
column2: The MS performs network selection for disaster roaming services during automatic network selection mode if: The MS supports MINT. Disaster roaming is enabled in the UE.There is no available PLMN that is allowable. The MS is not in 5GMM-REGISTERED state and 5GMM-CONNECTED mode over non-3GPP access. The MS does not have a PDN connection via an ePDG connected to EPC.An NG-RAN cell of the PLMN or a shared network where the PLMN is available broadcasts the disaster-related indication or a list of PLMNs with disaster condition, and the conditions specified are met.

column1: What are the conditions under which the Mobile Station (MS) may indicate to the user that certain Public Land Mobile Networks (PLMNs) support disaster roaming services?
column2: The MS may indicate to the user that certain PLMNs support disaster roaming services if: Only forbidden PLMNs are available. The MS receives an indication that some forbidden PLMNs provide disaster roaming services to the MS(s) of the Registered PLMN (RPLMN). Conditions specified in clause 4.4.3.1.1 are met.

column1: When the MS supports Closed Access Groups (CAG), what information is presented to the user for each PLMN/access technology combination of NG-RAN access technology?
column2: When the MS supports CAG, the following information is presented for each PLMN/access technology combination of NG-RAN access technology: The PLMN/access technology combination and a list of CAG-IDs. For each CAG-ID, information on the availability of a CAG cell broadcasting the CAG-ID for the PLMN, and whether the CAG-ID is authorized based on the "Allowed CAG list."

column1: What happens during the registration process when the MS has a PDU session for emergency services, a PDN connection for emergency bearer services, or a CS emergency call?
column2: During the registration process, if the MS has, or is establishing, a PDU session for emergency services, a PDN connection for emergency bearer services, or a CS emergency call, manual network selection shall not be performed.

column1: Under what conditions may the MS automatically register on a different PLMN after the user has manually selected a PLMN?
column2: The MS may automatically register on a different PLMN if: The MS supports MINT. The "list of PLMN(s) to be used in disaster condition" is non-empty. No available PLMN is declared as an equivalent PLMN by the RPLMN. The RPLMN of the MS is considered as the MS determined PLMN with disaster condition.

column1: How does the MS handle manual CSG selection within the RPLMN?
column2: If the user selects a CSG within the RPLMN, the MS shall attempt to register on a cell that corresponds to the CSG. Upon successful or unsuccessful completion of the registration or if registration is not possible, the MS shall return to automatic CSG selection mode.These questions cover different aspects of the provided text, and you can use them for fine-tuning a model on the specific domain knowledge related to mobile network selection.

column1: What is the purpose of the Manual Network Selection Mode in the context of clause 4.4.3.2.2?
column2: The Manual Network Selection Mode in clause 4.4.3.2.2 is used for...

column1: Explain the procedure outlined in clause 4.4.3.2.3 regarding Manual CSG selection.
column2: The procedure specified in clause 4.4.3.2.3 for Manual CSG selection involves...

column1: What are the conditions under which Automatic and manual network selection modes operate in VPLMN when not registered for disaster roaming services?
column2: In VPLMN, when not registered for disaster roaming services, Automatic and manual network selection modes are applicable if...

column1: How is the timer 'T' interpreted based on the radio capabilities supported by the MS?
column2: The interpretation of timer 'T' depends on the radio capabilities supported by the MS. For an MS that does not support...

column1: Under what circumstances does the MS make periodic attempts to obtain service on its HPLMN or EHPLMNs in VPLMN?
column2: The MS makes periodic attempts to obtain service on its HPLMN or EHPLMNs in VPLMN when...

column1: What conditions must be met for the MS to perform periodic attempts in automatic mode while roaming?
column2: The MS performs periodic attempts in automatic mode while roaming only when...

column1: How does the MS handle the timer 'T' when it activates power saving mode (PSM) or mobile-initiated connection only mode (MICO)?
column2: The MS does not stop timer 'T' when activating power saving mode (PSM) or mobile-initiated connection only mode (MICO), as described in...

column1: What are the conditions for enabling Fast First Higher Priority PLMN search, and how does it affect the attempts to access higher priority PLMNs?
column2: Fast First Higher Priority PLMN search is enabled when...

column1: Explain the exceptions to the rule regarding PLMN selection based on MCC values in satellite NG-RAN access or satellite E-UTRAN access with a shared MCC.
column2: Exceptions to the rule regarding PLMN selection based on MCC values in satellite NG-RAN access or satellite E-UTRAN access with a shared MCC are...

column1: In signal level enhanced network selection, what criteria must be met for the MS to select a PLMN?
column2: In signal level enhanced network selection, the MS selects a PLMN if...

column1: What is the procedure for Automatic and manual network selection modes when the MS is registered for disaster roaming services?
column2: When the MS is registered for disaster roaming services, it periodically attempts to obtain service on an allowable PLMN of the same country as the current serving PLMN. The procedure follows the requirements outlined in the Automatic Network Selection Mode in clause 4.4.3.1.1.

column1: How is timer 'T' interpreted when the MS is registered for disaster roaming services?
column2: When the MS is registered for disaster roaming services, timer 'T' is either in the range of 30 minutes to 40 hours in 30-minute steps, or it indicates that no periodic attempts shall be made. If no value for 'T' is stored in the SIM, a default value of 60 minutes is used.

column1: Under what conditions does the MS make periodic attempts to obtain service on an allowable PLMN when registered for disaster roaming services?
column2: The MS makes periodic attempts in automatic mode when registered for disaster roaming services and does not have a PDU session for emergency services. The first attempt is made after a period of at least 2 minutes and at most the time configured for 'T' upon selecting a VPLMN for disaster roaming.

column1: What are the conditions for postponing periodic attempts while the MS is in power saving mode (PSM)?
column2: Periodic attempts may be postponed while the MS is in power saving mode (PSM), as well as in various other conditions including receiving eMBMS transport service, receiving broadcast MBS service, eDRX configuration, relaxed monitoring, Mobile Initiated Connection Only mode (MICO), and while the unavailability period is activated in the MS.

column1: Explain the procedure of Manual CSG selection outlined in clause 4.4.3.3.2.
column2: The procedure of Manual CSG selection, as specified in clause 4.4.3.1.3, is followed.

column1: When is the Investigation Scan for higher prioritized PLMN initiated, and what conditions must be met for an MS to perform this scan?
column2: The Investigation Scan for higher prioritized PLMN is initiated after each successful PLMN selection and registration when the MS is in idle mode or when the MS is unable to obtain normal service from a PLMN (limited service state). The scan is performed if the MS is capable of both voice and packet data and if the selected PLMN is not already the highest prioritized PLMN in the current country.

column1: What conditions trigger the Periodic attempts for signal level enhanced network selection, and how does the MS determine if an attempt is necessary?
column2: The Periodic attempts for signal level enhanced network selection are triggered when signal level enhancement is applicable, and the received signal quality of the registered PLMN observed over an averaging window is lower than the "Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology." The MS starts the attempt if, upon registration or later, it detects that the received signal quality of the current cell is below the threshold.

column1: How does the MS handle periodic attempts for signal level enhanced network selection during power-saving mode (PSM) or mobile-initiated connection only mode (MICO)?
column2: The MS does not stop timer 'TSENSE' during power-saving mode (PSM) or mobile-initiated connection only mode (MICO). The attempts are performed only in automatic mode and not while the MS is attached for emergency bearer services, registered for emergency services, has a PDN connection for emergency bearer services, or has a PDU session for emergency services.

column1: What happens when there is no SIM in the MS, or an authentication failure occurs?
column2: If there is no SIM in the MS or an authentication failure occurs, the MS enters the "No SIM" state. In such cases, no PLMN selection information is used, and no attempts at registration on any PLMN are made until the MS is switched off and on again or a SIM is inserted.

column1: What triggers the user reselection procedure in Automatic Network Selection mode when the MS is in the "not updated" state?
column2: In Automatic Network Selection mode, when the MS is in the "not updated" state with one or more suitable cells to camp on, and after the maximum allowed unsuccessful LR requests, the user reselection procedure of clause 4.4.3.2.1 may be continued or started by the MS.

column1: How does the MS handle LR response "Roaming not allowed in this LA" or "Roaming not allowed in this TA"?
column2: If the LR response indicates "Roaming not allowed in this LA" or "Roaming not allowed in this TA," the PLMN Automatic or Manual Mode Selection Procedure of clause 4.4.3.1 is followed, depending on whether the MS is in automatic or manual mode.

column1: What actions does the MS take when it receives a USAT REFRESH command qualifier of type "Steering of Roaming"?
column2: When the MS receives a USAT REFRESH command qualifier of type "Steering of Roaming," it replaces the highest priority entries in the "Operator Controlled PLMN Selector with Access Technology" list, deletes PLMNs from the Forbidden PLMN list, considers new information in subsequent attempts to access a higher priority PLMN, and attempts to obtain service on a higher priority PLMN as specified in clause 4.4.3.3.

column1: Describe the general actions taken by the location registration process when the MS is switched on and capable of services requiring registration.
column2: The general actions taken by the location registration process when the MS is switched on are: If SIM is present and no LR is needed, the MS is in the "Updated" state. If SIM is present and LR is needed, a LR request is made.If no SIM is present, the MS enters the update state "Idle, No IMSI."

column1: What triggers an LR request indicating Normal Updating in idle mode?
column2: An LR request indicating Normal Updating is triggered when the MS changes cell while the update status is "NOT UPDATED," or the MS detects a new registration area, or the MS detects it has entered a new registration area while attached for access to RLOS, among other conditions listed in clause 4.5.2.

column1: Under what conditions does an LR request indicating Periodic Location Updating occur?
column2: An LR request indicating Periodic Location Updating occurs when the periodic location updating timer expires while the non-GPRS update status is "UPDATED."

column1: Explain the characteristics of the Periodic Location Updating timer.
column2: The Periodic Location Updating timer, for non-GPRS operation, is loaded with a random value between 0 and the broadcast or signaled time-out value upon MS switch on. The time-out value is within the range of 1 deci hour to 255 deci hours with a granularity of 1 deci hour. When the timer expires, the MS initiates periodic location registration corresponding to the expired timer. The timer is prevented from triggering during connected mode.

column1: What does the IMSI attach/detach indicator in the system information specify?
column2: The IMSI attach/detach indicator in the system information specifies whether IMSI attach/detach operation is mandatory to use in the cell.

column1: When does a GPRS MS perform GPRS attach/detach procedures?
column2: A GPRS MS shall perform GPRS attach/detach procedures independent of the value of the IMSI attach/detach indicator.

column1: What action should an MS take when IMSI detach operation applies?
column2: When IMSI detach operation applies, an MS shall send the IMSI detach message to the network when the MS is powered down or the SIM is removed while the update status is "UPDATED."

column1: In the SNPN selection process, what are the two SNPN selection modes?
column2: The two SNPN selection modes are automatic SNPN selection mode and manual SNPN selection mode.

column1: Under what conditions should an MS listen to all paging messages?
column2: An MS is required to listen to all paging messages when conditions such as having a SIM inserted, being camped on a cell, and not performing tasks to search for available PLMNs or available SNPNs are satisfied.

column1: What is the purpose of the MM Restart Procedure?
column2: The MM Restart Procedure is needed in some cases, such as on a change of SIM data, to restart the MM without the need for user intervention.

column1: What does the service indication in A/Gb mode signify?
column2: The service indication in A/Gb mode indicates to the user that service or CTS service is available.

column1: When should an MS send the IMSI detach message to the network?
column2: An MS should send the IMSI detach message to the network when the MS is powered down or the SIM is removed while the update status is "UPDATED."

column1: How does an MS handle the LR response "No Suitable Cells In Location Area" during location registration?
column2: If the LR response "No Suitable Cells In Location Area" is received, the MS shall attempt to find another LA or TA of the same PLMN or an equivalent PLMN on which it received the LR response.

column1: When should the service indication be set in A/Gb mode?
column2: The service indication should be set if the MS is camped on a suitable cell and in an updated state, or in connected mode having been camped on a suitable cell.
column3: The provided tables and notes outline the various states and outcomes of the Location Registration (LR) process in a mobile communication system. Table 1 details the effects of LR outcomes on Public Land Mobile Network (PLMN) registration, including states like "Updated" and "Idle, No IMSI," with corresponding registration statuses and actions. Additionally, specific scenarios under "Roaming not allowed" are addressed. Table 2 illustrates LR process states and allowed actions, considering tasks like changing cells, registration areas, and PLMNs. Notes provide additional context, highlighting that mobile stations capable of GPRS and non-GPRS services may have different registration statuses. The overall process involves actions like cell selection, PLMN selection, and LR attempts, with considerations for various conditions and restrictions. The diagrams and explanations depict a comprehensive overview of the LR process and associated states in the mobile communication system.

column1: What is the procedure for the MS when it needs to access an SNPN for onboarding services in SNPN?
column2: The MS shall select an SNPN indicating that onboarding is allowed, matching the onboarding SNPN selection information if pre-configured, and limit its search to the NG-RAN access technology.

column1: What happens if more than one SNPN indicating onboarding is allowed and matching the selection information are available during SNPN selection?
column2: If more than one such SNPN is available, how the MS selects one of those SNPNs is MS implementation specific.

column1: What is the MS required to do once it selects an SNPN during the onboarding services procedure?
column2: The MS shall attempt initial registration for onboarding services on the selected SNPN using the NG-RAN access technology and default UE credentials for primary authentication.

column1: In case of unsuccessful registration for onboarding services, what options does the MS have?
column2: If unsuccessful registration occurs, the MS may indicate no onboarding services to upper layers, enter a limited service state, and wait until a new SNPN indicating onboarding is allowed becomes available.

column1: Explain the procedure for manual SNPN selection mode for onboarding services.
column2: The MS shall indicate to upper layers one or more SNPNs available for onboarding services, limit its search to NG-RAN access technology, and for each SNPN indicated, provide information such as whether it matches onboarding SNPN selection information and the human-readable network name.

column1: What happens when access for localized services in SNPN is changed or when the validity information of the selected SNPN is no longer met?
column2: If the MS supports access to an SNPN providing access for localized services, is in automatic SNPN selection mode, and access for localized services changes or the validity information is no longer met, the MS may perform SNPN selection according to the specified procedure.

column1: Under what conditions can a user initiate reselection and registration onto an available SNPN?
column2: The user may request reselection and registration onto an available SNPN if there is at least one entry in the "list of subscriber data" or if the MS has a USIM with a PLMN subscription and is provisioned with SNPN selection parameters.

column1: What is the procedure for automatic SNPN selection mode during user reselection?
column2: The MS shall select an SNPN based on certain criteria, excluding the previously selected SNPN, and attempt registration on the selected SNPN using NG-RAN access technology, subscriber identifier, and credentials.

column1: When does the manual SNPN selection mode procedure for user reselection take place?
column2: The manual SNPN selection mode procedure of clause 4.9.3.1.2 is followed during user reselection.

column1: In what cases does an "No SIM" state occur, and what actions are taken in this state?
column2: An "No SIM" state occurs when specific conditions are met, such as authentication failures or "illegal ME" or "illegal UE" responses. In this state, the MS may perform SNPN selection for onboarding services in SNPN, but no further attempts at registration on any SNPN are made until certain events occur, such as switching off and on again, updating "list of subscriber data," or inserting the USIM.

column1: What is the purpose of the Location Registration (LR) process in a mobile communication system?
column2: The Location Registration (LR) process in a mobile communication system serves to update the network with the current location of a mobile device. It involves tasks such as cell selection, registration area updates, and PLMN selection.

column1: Why might a mobile device enter the "Roaming not allowed" state during Location Registration?
column2: A mobile device may enter the "Roaming not allowed" state during Location Registration due to reasons such as the PLMN not being allowed, the Location Area (LA) or Tracking Area (TA) being restricted, or the device not being authorized for a specific Closed Subscriber Group (CSG).

column1: In the LR Process States and Allowed Actions table, what actions are allowed when the mobile device is in the "Updated" state?
column2: In the "Updated" state, the mobile device is allowed to change cells, change registration areas, change PLMN, and perform other supported actions. Normal calls and paging responses are also supported in this state.

column1: What are the conditions under which the "Idle, No IMSI" state is entered for GPRS and non-GPRS services?
column2: The "Idle, No IMSI" state is entered based on specified conditions, as outlined in clause 4.3.3. These conditions may vary for GPRS and non-GPRS services, and the details are specified in the protocol.

column1: Explain the steps involved in the Overall Idle Mode process as depicted in Figure 1.
column2: The Overall Idle Mode process involves steps such as setting the PLMN selection mode, presenting available PLMNs to the user, manual PLMN selection, and CSG-related procedures if the device supports CSGs. It culminates in cell selection, location registration, and potential LR attempts.

column1: What is the goal of the PLMN selection process for a multi-mode MS supporting access technologies defined by both 3GPP and 3GPP2?
column2: The goal is to find the highest priority PLMN and attempt to register to it.

column1: In the context of HPLMN matching criteria, what is the significance of the hexadecimal code "F" in the 3rd digit of the BCCH-MNC for PCS1900 in North America?
column2: If the 3rd digit is Hex F, it indicates a transition period, and further matching criteria are applied according to the rules specified.

column1: Explain the process for HPLMN matching criteria in mobiles that don't support PCS1900 for North America.
column2: Compare all 3 digits of the SIM-MCC with the BCCH-MCC. If they don't match, the HPLMN match fails. Read the 3rd digit of the BCCH-MNC. If it is Hex F, proceed to step (4). Compare all 3 digits of the SIM-MNC with the BCCH-MNC. If they match, the HPLMN match succeeds; otherwise, it fails. Compare just the 1st 2 digits of the SIM-MNC with the BCCH-MNC. If they match, the HPLMN match succeeds; otherwise, it fails.

column1: What additional step is involved in the HPLMN matching criteria for mobiles supporting PCS1900 for North America?
column2: 4.1 Determine if the BCCH-MCC lies in the range 310-316 (PCS1900 for NA network). 4.2 If outside the range, proceed to step (6). 4.3 Compare the 3rd digit of the SIM-MNC with '0'. If not '0', the HPLMN match fails. 4.4 Compare just the 1st 2 digits of the SIM-MNC with the BCCH-MNC. If they match, the HPLMN match succeeds; otherwise, it fails.

column1: When does an MS consider the VPLMN and a PLMN to be of the same country while roaming?
column2: While roaming on a VPLMN, the VPLMN and a PLMN are considered of the same country only if their MCC values identify the same country.

column1: What guidelines are provided for networks in PCS1900 for North America during the transition period from broadcasting 2 MNC digits to broadcasting 3 MNC digits?
column2: Existing network codes using a 2-digit BCCH-MNC (xy) should use the new code xy0.New operators allocated 3-digit MNC codes with the same 1st 2 digits as an existing operator should not use a 3rd digit of 0.

column1: What is the purpose of the control plane solution for steering of roaming in 5GS procedure in a PLMN?
column2: The purpose of the control plane solution for steering of roaming in 5GS procedure in a PLMN is to allow the HPLMN to update one or more of the following via NAS signaling: a) the "Operator Controlled PLMN Selector with Access Technology" list in the UE; b) the SOR-CMCI (Steering of Roaming Connected Mode Control Information); c) the SOR-SNPN-SI (Steering of Roaming Selected Network Public Name - Slice Information) associated with the selected PLMN subscription in the Mobile Equipment (ME); d) the SOR-SNPN-SI-LS (Steering of Roaming Selected Network Public Name - Slice Information - Location Service) associated with the selected PLMN subscription in the ME; e) the SOR-SENSE (Operator controlled signal threshold per access technology);f) the slice-based PLMN selection information.

column1: Under what conditions can the HPLMN provide the steering of roaming information to the UE during initial registration in a VPLMN?
column2: If the UE's USIM is configured to indicate that the UE is expected to receive the steering of roaming information during the initial registration procedure in a VPLMN, and if such configuration is provided in the USIM, then it is mandatory for the HPLMN to provide the steering of roaming information to the UE during initial registration in a VPLMN. If such configuration is not provided in the USIM, it is optional for the HPLMN to provide the steering of roaming information to the UE during initial registration, based on operator policy.

column1: What role does the SOR-CMCI (Steering of Roaming Connected Mode Control Information) play in the control plane solution for steering of roaming in 5GS?
column2: The SOR-CMCI enables the HPLMN to control the timing of a UE in 5GS connected mode to move to idle mode for performing the steering of roaming. The UE shall support the SOR-CMCI, and the HPLMN may configure it in the UE or send it over N1 NAS signaling. The SOR-CMCI received over N1 NAS signaling takes precedence over the SOR-CMCI configured in the UE. The HPLMN can consider user preferences for services not to be interrupted due to steering of roaming when setting the SOR-CMCI.

column1: What is the purpose of the SOR-SNPN-SI-LS (Steering of Roaming Selected Network Public Name - Slice Information - Location Service)?
column2: The SOR-SNPN-SI-LS is used to support access to an SNPN providing access for localized services in SNPN. If the UE supports access to an SNPN using credentials from a credentials holder, the UE shall indicate ME's support for SOR-SNPN-SI-LS to the HPLMN or subscribed SNPN. The HPLMN or subscribed SNPN can use the SOR-SNPN-SI-LS to update the selected entry of "list of subscriber data" or the selected PLMN subscription in the ME, based on policies related to the registered SNPN, the location of the UE, etc.

column1: When does the UE remove a PLMN from the list of "PLMNs where registration was aborted due to SOR"?
column2: The UE removes a PLMN from the list of "PLMNs where registration was aborted due to SOR" if the UE receives steering of roaming information in the REGISTRATION ACCEPT or DL NAS TRANSPORT message, and the security check to verify that the steering of roaming information is provided by HPLMN is successful. The UE deletes the list when the MS is switched off, the USIM is removed, or after a UE implementation-dependent time.

column1: What is the procedure for providing the list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations and the SOR-CMCI during registration in VPLMN?
column2: The procedure involves the UE initiating initial registration, emergency registration, or registration procedure for mobility and periodic registration update to the VPLMN AMF. The AMF provides the registration type to the UDM, and based on operator policies, the HPLMN UDM may provide the list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations and the SOR-CMCI to the UE. The UE then performs registration with the VPLMN, considering the provided steering of roaming information.

column1: Under what conditions does the HPLMN provide the steering of roaming information to the UE during initial registration in a VPLMN?
column2: If the user subscription information indicates to send the steering of roaming information due to initial registration in a VPLMN, then the HPLMN UDM shall provide the steering of roaming information to the UE during initial registration in a VPLMN. Otherwise, the HPLMN UDM may provide the steering of roaming information to the UE based on operator policy.

column1: What are the conditions under which the secured packet obtained by the UDM can include SOR-CMCI?
column2: The secured packet obtained by the UDM can include SOR-CMCI only if the "ME support of SOR-CMCI" indicator is stored for the UE, and the USIM of the indicated SUPI supports SOR-CMCI.

column1: In the communication between the HPLMN UDM and the SOR-AF, what information is exchanged in the Nsoraf_SoR_Get request?
column2: The HPLMN UDM sends an Nsoraf_SoR_Get request to the SOR-AF, including the VPLMN ID, SUPI of the UE, and access type parameters.

column1: What actions does the SOR-AF take in response to the Nsoraf_SoR_Get request from the HPLMN UDM?
column2: The SOR-AF responds with an Nsoraf_SoR_Get response, including the list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations, SOR-CMCI (if any), and the "Store SOR-CMCI in ME" indicator or the secured packet, based on operator-specific criteria.

column1: When does the HPLMN UDM form the steering of roaming information, and what parameters does it use?
column2: The HPLMN UDM forms the steering of roaming information in step 3d, using the list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations, SOR-CMCI (if any), and the "Store SOR-CMCI in ME" indicator obtained in step 3a or 3c.

column1: In the registration procedure, what role does the VPLMN AMF play in handling the steering of roaming information?
column2: As part of the registration procedure, the VPLMN AMF receives the steering of roaming information from the HPLMN UDM, includes it in the Access and Mobility Subscription data, and subscribes to changes in the subscription data.

column1: What actions does the UE take if the steering of roaming information contains a secured packet?
column2: If the steering of roaming information contains a secured packet, the UE may upload the secured packet to the USIM, and if applicable, handle USAT REFRESH commands based on the SOR-CMCI and perform actions specified in clause 4.4.6.

column1: When does the UE acknowledge the successful security check of the received steering of roaming information?
column2: The UE acknowledges the successful security check in the Nudm_SDM_Get response service operation, and the acknowledgment may be requested by the HPLMN UDM based on its policy.

column1: How does the UE handle the steering of roaming information if a higher priority PLMN is detected?
column2: If a higher priority PLMN is detected and the UE is in automatic network selection mode, it may release the current N1 NAS signaling connection locally and attempt to obtain service on the higher priority PLMN.

column1: What steps does the UE take if the steering of roaming information is received during initial registration in a VPLMN?
column2: During initial registration in a VPLMN, the UE may follow steps specified in clause 4.4.3.3, and if applicable, acknowledge the successful security check as part of the Nudm_SDM_Get response.

column1: What actions does the HPLMN UDM take when providing information to the SOR-AF in Nsoraf_SoR_Info?
column2: The HPLMN UDM may include relevant indicators such as "ME support of SOR-CMCI," "ME support of SOR-SNPN-SI," and "ME support of SOR-SNPN-SI-LS" in the Nsoraf_SoR_Info service operation, informing the SOR-AF about the UE's capabilities.

column1: What is the trigger for the procedure described in Figure C.3.1 for steering UE in HPLMN or VPLMN after registration?
column2: The procedure is triggered when the HPLMN UDM receives a new list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations or a secured packet for a UE identified by SUPI from the SOR-AF.

column1: In what scenario does the SOR-AF include SOR-CMCI in the secured packet provided to the HPLMN UDM?
column2: The SOR-AF includes SOR-CMCI in the secured packet if it determines that the ME supports SOR-CMCI and the USIM of the indicated SUPI supports SOR-CMCI.

column1: What does the SOR-AF do before providing the HPLMN UDM with a new list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations?
column2: Before providing the new list, the SOR-AF can obtain user location information by triggering the unified location service exposure procedure based on operator policies or criteria.

column1: How does the UE handle a USAT REFRESH command of type "Steering of Roaming" when no SOR-CMCI is included or the UE is configured with SOR-CMCI?
column2: If no SOR-CMCI is included or the UE is configured with SOR-CMCI, the UE shall perform specific actions as defined in the procedure for steering of roaming in clause 4.4.6.

column1: When is Step 5 skipped in the procedure for providing a list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations and SOR-CMCI after registration?
column2: Step 5 is skipped if the UDM has not requested an acknowledgement from the UE in the DL NAS TRANSPORT message.

column1: What does the UE do if the security check is not successful, and the UE is in automatic network selection mode, and the selected PLMN is a VPLMN?
column2: The UE shall wait until it moves to idle mode or 5GMM-CONNECTED mode before attempting to obtain service on a higher priority PLMN, considering the current registered PLMN as lowest priority.

column1: How does the HPLMN UDM inform the SOR-AF about the successful delivery of the list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations?
column2: The HPLMN UDM uses the Nsoraf_SoR_Info service operation, including the necessary indicators, to inform the SOR-AF about the successful delivery.

column1: What action does the UE take if the selected PLMN is the HPLMN, and the UE has an established emergency PDU session?
column2: The UE shall not perform the PLMN selection, regardless of whether it is in automatic or manual network selection mode.

column1: What is the role of the HPLMN UDM when the UE acknowledges successful security check of the received steering of roaming information?
column2: The HPLMN UDM verifies the acknowledgement provided by the UE and stores or deletes indicators based on the information in the SOR transparent container.

column1: In what scenario does the UE release the current N1 NAS signalling connection and attempt to obtain service on a higher priority PLMN?
column2: The UE releases the current N1 NAS signalling connection and attempts to obtain service on a higher priority PLMN if the security check is not successful, and the UE is in automatic network selection mode with no ongoing PDU sessions or services.

column1: What is the purpose of SOR-CMCI in the 5G control plane for roaming?
column2: The purpose of SOR-CMCI (Steering of Roaming Control Mode Change Information) is to enable the Home Public Land Mobile Network (HPLMN) or subscribed Selected Public Land Mobile Network (SNPN) to control the timing of the User Equipment (UE) entering idle mode and performing higher-priority PLMN/access technology or SNPN selection during roaming.

column1: How is the SOR-CMCI configured and provided to the UE?
column2: The HPLMN or subscribed SNPN may configure the SOR-CMCI in the UE and provide it over N1 NAS signalling. The SOR-CMCI received over N1 NAS signalling takes precedence over the SOR-CMCI stored in the non-volatile memory of the Mobile Equipment (ME) or stored in the User Identity Module (USIM). It can be provided in plain text or within a secured packet.

column1: What happens if the UE receives SOR information without SOR-CMCI or security check failure occurs?
column2: If the UE receives SOR information without SOR-CMCI or the security check of received SOR information fails, the UE shall use the stored SOR-CMCI in the non-volatile memory of the ME, if available. If no SOR-CMCI is stored, the UE uses the SOR-CMCI stored in the USIM, if available. The UE deletes the stored SOR-CMCI in the ME when certain conditions are met.

column1: Describe the structure of SOR-CMCI rules.
column2: SOR-CMCI consists of rules, each with a criterion (PDU session attribute type, service type, SOR security check, or match all type) and a Tsor-cm timer value indicating the time the UE waits before releasing PDU sessions or services and entering idle mode. Rules include criteria such as DNN of the PDU session, S-NSSAI STT of the PDU session, S-NSSAI SST and SD of the PDU session, service types like IMS registration, MMTEL voice call, MMTEL video call, SMS over NAS or SMSoIP, SOR security check, and match all.

column1: What exemptions exist for services during SOR-CMCI application?
column2: Emergency services are exempted from being forced to release related established PDU sessions and enter idle mode during SOR-CMCI application. Additionally, a UE configured with high priority access in the selected PLMN or SNPN considers all services and related established PDU sessions exempt from forced release during SOR-CMCI application.

column1: How does the UE apply SOR-CMCI during the SOR procedure?
column2: During the SOR procedure, the UE applies SOR-CMCI by determining the time to release PDU sessions or services based on criteria such as security check status and matching rules. The UE starts Tsor-cm timers associated with specific criteria and stops or starts timers based on ongoing services. The UE also considers exemptions and prioritizes based on PLMN or SNPN selection mode.

column1: What happens if the UE switches to manual network selection mode during SOR-CMCI application?
column2: If the UE switches to manual network selection mode during SOR-CMCI application, it shall stop any running Tsor-cm timers. In this case, the UE is not required to enter idle mode and perform the de-registration procedure.

column1: Describe the stage-2 flow for providing UE with SOR-CMCI after registration.
column2: The stage-2 flow involves the SOR-AF triggering the UDM to update the UE with SOR-CMCI. The UDM notifies the AMF of user profile changes, and the AMF sends the steering of roaming information to the UE. The UE performs a security check, stores SOR-CMCI, and may acknowledge back to the AMF. The UDM informs the SOR-AF of successful delivery if required.

column1: What triggers the initiation of the registration procedure according to the described stage-2 flow?
column2: The registration procedure is initiated when the UE sends a REGISTRATION REQUEST message to the AMF, indicating "initial registration," "emergency registration," or "mobility registration updating" in the 5GS registration type Information Element (IE).

column1: What service operation does the AMF invoke when it does not have subscription data for the UE during registration?
column2: In such a case, the AMF invokes the Nudm_SDM_Get service operation to the UDM to obtain, among other information, the Access and Mobility Subscription data for the UE.

column1: In what scenarios does the UDM provide the steering of roaming information to the UE during initial registration?
column2: The UDM provides the steering of roaming information to the UE during initial registration in a non-subscribed SNPN if the user subscription information indicates it. Otherwise, for registration on a subscribed SNPN, it depends on the UE's indication of support for SOR-SNPN-SI in the REGISTRATION REQUEST message.

column1: What actions does the UDM take if the UE is registering in a non-subscribed SNPN, and the subscribed SNPN or HPLMN policy for the SOR-AF invocation is absent?
column2: The UDM obtains the available SOR-SNPN-SI, and if the "ME support of SOR-CMCI" or "ME support of SOR-SNPN-SI-LS" indicators are stored for the UE, it may obtain the corresponding information.

column1: How does the UE handle the received steering of roaming information during registration?
column2: If the security check is successful, the UE sends the REGISTRATION COMPLETE message to the AMF with the received steering of roaming information. It may also perform actions such as SNPN selection based on priorities.

column1: Under what conditions does the UE release the current N1 NAS signalling connection during SNPN selection?
column2: The UE releases the current N1 NAS signalling connection if it is in automatic network selection mode and needs to obtain service on a higher priority SNPN, as specified in clause 4.9.3 of the procedure.

column1: What happens if the UE is configured to receive the steering of roaming information, but it is not provided in the REGISTRATION ACCEPT message?
column2: If the steering of roaming information is not provided, the UE may take actions like releasing the current N1 NAS signalling connection and attempting to obtain service on a higher priority SNPN.

column1: What is the role of the AMF in handling the steering of roaming information during the registration procedure?
column2: The AMF subscribes to changes in subscription data, including updates to the steering of roaming information, using the Nudm_SDM_Subscribe service operation.

column1: In what circumstances does the UE acknowledge the successful security check of the received steering of roaming information?
column2: The UE acknowledges the successful security check if the UDM has requested an acknowledgement, and the UE has verified that the steering of roaming information has been provided by the subscribed SNPN or HPLMN.

column1: What service operation does the UDM use to inform the SOR-AF about the successful delivery of the SOR-SNPN-SI to the UE?
column2: The UDM uses the Nsoraf_SoR_Info service operation, including information such as the SUPI of the UE, successful delivery, "ME support of SOR-CMCI" indicator, and "ME support of SOR-SNPN-SI-LS" indicator.

column1: What triggers the procedure for steering the UE in SNPN after registration?
column2: The procedure for steering the UE in SNPN after registration is triggered if the UDM supports obtaining SOR-SNPN-SI, SOR-CMCI, or SOR-SNPN-SI-LS from the SOR-AF, and certain conditions related to policies are met.

column1: How can the SOR-AF determine whether the Mobile Equipment (ME) supports SOR-SNPN-SI?
column2: The SOR-AF can determine that the ME supports SOR-SNPN-SI if the Nsoraf_SoR_Info service operation has returned the "ME support of SOR-SNPN-SI" indicator. The UDM determines ME support based on information received from the AMF.

column1: In which situations does the UE perform SNPN selection in automatic network selection mode?
column2: If the UE is in automatic network selection mode, the selected SNPN is a non-subscribed SNPN, and certain conditions are met, the UE may perform SNPN selection. The specific conditions are outlined in the provided text.

column1: What information does the UDM include in the Nudm_SDM_Notification service operation to the affected AMF?
column2: The UDM includes the steering of roaming information, such as SOR-SNPN-SI and SOR-CMCI, in the Nudm_SDM_Notification service operation to notify the affected AMF of user profile changes.

column1: What actions does the UE take upon successful security check of the steering of roaming information?
column2: Upon successful security check, the UE performs actions like updating prioritized lists, acknowledging the UE in certain cases, and applying SNPN selection based on the received information.

column1: How does the UE handle security check failure of SOR information in DL NAS TRANSPORT message?
column2: If the UE encounters security check failure of SOR information in DL NAS TRANSPORT message and switches to automatic network selection mode, it waits until it moves to idle mode or 5GMM-CONNECTED mode before attempting to obtain service on a higher priority SNPN.

column1: When does the UDM inform the SOR-AF about successful delivery of SOR-SNPN-SI, SOR-CMCI, and SOR-SNPN-SI-LS to the UE?
column2: The UDM informs the SOR-AF about successful delivery of SOR-SNPN-SI, SOR-CMCI, and SOR-SNPN-SI-LS to the UE if the selected SNPN is a non-subscribed SNPN and the UE is in automatic network selection mode, and certain conditions are met.

column1: What does the UE do if the security check is not successful upon receiving the steering of roaming information?
column2: If the security check is not successful, the UE skips certain steps, and if in automatic network selection mode, it may perform SNPN selection based on specified conditions.

column1: How does the SOR-AF determine the ME support of SOR-CMCI?
column2: The SOR-AF can determine that the ME supports SOR-CMCI if the Nsoraf_SoR_Info service operation has returned the "ME support of SOR-CMCI" indicator. The specific method by which SOR-AF determines USIM support for SOR-CMCI is implementation-specific.

column1: What is included in the DL NAS TRANSPORT message sent from the AMF to the UE?
column2: The DL NAS TRANSPORT message includes the steering of roaming information received from the UDM, and the UE performs a security check on this information upon receipt.

column1: What is the purpose of the procedure described in Figure C.8.1?
column2: The procedure in Figure C.8.1 is for configuring a UE with a list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations in an SNPN after registration.

column1: How is the list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations delivered to the UE according to HPLMN policy?
column2: The list is sent in plain text or within a secured packet to the UE, triggered by either the UDM receiving a new list from the SOR-AF or the UDM having a new list retrieved from the UDR.

column1: What does the UE do upon receiving the steering of roaming information in the DL NAS TRANSPORT message?
column2: The UE performs a security check and, if successful, uploads a secured packet to the USIM (if applicable) and updates its list of preferred PLMN/access technology combinations.

column1: How does the UE handle a security check failure in automatic network selection mode?
column2: If the security check fails and the UE is in automatic network selection mode, it follows specific actions based on whether it has a stored SOR-CMCI or not.

column1: What happens if the UE is in the manual mode of operation during the steering of roaming information reception?
column2: If the UE is in manual mode or the current chosen non-subscribed SNPN is part of the user-controlled prioritized list, it stays on the current chosen non-subscribed SNPN.

column1: What information does the UDM provide to the SOR-AF upon successful delivery of steering of roaming information?
column2: The UDM informs the SOR-AF about successful delivery using Nsoraf_SoR_Info, including the UE's SUPI, successful delivery status, and the "ME support of SOR-SNPN-SI" indicator.

column1: What is described in Annex D (informative): Change history?
column2: Annex D provides the change history of the specification, including the TSG number, Tdoc, version, CR (Change Request) details, and comments.

column1: What change was made in version 3.1.1 according to the change history?
column2: The entry #4 (N1-99573) for PLMN selection for GPRS mobiles was removed in version 3.1.1, where it is not approved by SMG2.

column1: What does the document define in Scope?
column2: The document defines the stage 2 service description for emergency services in the IP Multimedia Core Network Subsystem (IMS), including the elements necessary to support IP Multimedia (IM) emergency services and IM emergency services for eCall.
column3: The document outlines the stage 2 service description for emergency services in the IP Multimedia Core Network Subsystem (IMS), specifically focusing on IP Multimedia (IM) emergency services and IM emergency services for eCall. It follows the three-stage method for characterizing telecommunication services outlined in ITU T Recommendation I.130, with stage 2 defined by ITU T Recommendation Q.65. The coverage extends to Access Network aspects crucial for provisioning IMS emergency services and references various 3GPP specifications related to IMS, including those for IMS in general, GPRS, EPS, Non-3GPP access (WLAN), location services, and continuity for IMS emergency sessions. Non-3GPP specifications related to IMS emergency services are also included. The document provides a comprehensive list of references and definitions, including key terms such as Emergency Call Server (ECS), Emergency CSCF, Emergency Service Query Key (ESQK), and more. The informative Annex E describes emergency support in different IP-CANs. The document serves as a detailed guide for implementing and understanding emergency services in IMS, incorporating both 3GPP and non-3GPP specifications.

column1: According to ITU T Recommendation I.130, how is the characterisation of telecommunication services described?
column2: ITU T Recommendation I.130 describes a three-stage method for the characterisation of telecommunication services.

column1: What aspects does the document cover regarding IMS emergency services?
column2: The document also covers the Access Network aspects crucial for the provisioning of IMS emergency services.

column1: Name some 3GPP specifications related to IMS emergency services mentioned in the document.
What is the role of the Emergency CSCF?
column2: The Emergency CSCF handles certain aspects of emergency sessions, such as routing emergency requests to the correct emergency center or PSAP.

column1: What is NG-eCall (eCall Over IMS)?
column2: NG-eCall (eCall Over IMS) is a manually or automatically initiated IMS emergency call from a vehicle, supplemented with a minimum set of emergency-related initial data (MSD).

column1: Define the term "Charging Data Record."
column2: Charging Data Record is a record generated by a network element for the purpose of billing a subscriber for the provided service.

column1: According to ETSI ES 282 004, what does CLF register?
column2: CLF (Connectivity Session Location and Repository Function) registers the association between the IP address allocated to the UE and related network location information.

column1: What does the term "Emergency Service Query Key (ESQK)" refer to?
column2: Emergency Service Query Key (ESQK) is a 10-digit North American Numbering Plan number used to identify a particular emergency call instance.

column1: What is the function of the Location Retrieval Function (LRF)?
column2: The Location Retrieval Function (LRF) handles the retrieval of location information for the UE, including interim, initial, and updated location information.

column1: Define "Private Network Traffic" as per TS 24.229.
column2: Private Network Traffic refers to all traffic from UEs having registered a contact bound to a public user identity receiving hosted enterprise services.

column1: What is meant by "eCall Only Mode" according to TS 23.401?
column2: "eCall Only Mode" is described in TS 23.401 and refers to a specific mode outlined in the same document.

column1: What are the architectural principles for emergency sessions in the IMS?
column2: The architectural principles for emergency sessions in the IMS are outlined in TS 22.101 [8], TS 22.228 [27], and specific requirements as detailed in the document.
column3: In the context of IMS (IP Multimedia Subsystem) emergency sessions, the architectural principles aim to ensure effective handling of emergency calls over various access networks. The solution aligns with the emergency principles and requirements outlined in relevant specifications. Key architectural requirements include ensuring independence of emergency services from the IP-CAN (Connectivity Access Network), supporting emergency sessions over different access networks, and allowing the detection and routing of emergency sessions even in cases where the UE (User Equipment) cannot autonomously identify an emergency. The principles emphasize the importance of prioritizing emergency sessions over non-emergency sessions, allowing for emergency sessions even when the UE lacks sufficient credentials, and supporting emergency service requests with the same authentication and security methods as non-emergency requests. The architecture accounts for scenarios where UE registration with IMS (IP Multimedia Subsystem) is required for emergency services and outlines procedures for emergency registration. The solution also supports emergency sessions in cases of roaming, enabling UE-initiated emergency registration in the roamed-to network. Additionally, the principles address the interaction with emergency centers (PSAPs), highlighting the capability for PSAP call-backs to UE and the provision of location information to PSAPs. Privacy considerations are taken into account, allowing users to request the non-disclosure of information to PSAPs based on session-by-session preferences and local regulations. The architecture also includes provisions for supporting various media types during emergency sessions, such as voice, GTT (Generic Text Transfer), video, and text-based instant messaging, based on local regulations and UE capabilities. The handling of location information is a critical aspect, and the principles establish guidelines for including location information in emergency session requests. The solution supports querying the IP-CAN and the LRF (Location Retrieval Function) for location information validation and retrieval. Furthermore, it ensures compliance with regional regulations and specifies the routing of emergency sessions based on the capabilities of visited networks.In summary, the IMS emergency session architecture is designed to adhere to high-level principles ensuring effective, secure, and prioritized handling of emergency calls over diverse access networks, while also addressing privacy concerns and complying with regional regulations.

column1: What are the key requirements for emergency services independent from the IP-CAN?
column2: Emergency services should be independent from the IP-CAN with respect to the detection and routing of emergency sessions. They should be possible over various access networks, including cellular, fixed broadband, nomadic, WLAN access to EPC, and non-3GPP access to 5GC.

column1: How are emergency numbers and associated information handled when received via WLAN for EPC access?
column2: Emergency numbers and associated types or URN information received via WLAN for EPC access are only used for detecting emergency calls in the same country if permission from the PLMN selected in 3GPP access is received.

column1: What is the primary solution for the UE to detect an emergency session?
column2: The primary solution is that the UE can detect an emergency session (e.g., by evaluating the SIP-URI or the dialed number) by itself and indicates the emergency session to the network.

column1: In what scenarios should emergency sessions be prioritized over non-emergency sessions?
column2: Emergency sessions should be prioritized over non-emergency sessions by the system.

column1: How does the architecture handle emergency sessions for users with a barred public user identity?
column2: The architecture allows the establishment of IMS emergency sessions for users with a barred public user identity.

column1: What should the network do if the UE does not have sufficient credentials to authenticate with the IMS?
column2: If the UE does not have sufficient credentials to authenticate with the IMS, it shall perform an emergency registration for the support of emergency services.

column1: Is the Emergency Service a subscription service?
column2: No, the Emergency Service is not a subscription service.

column1: How are emergency sessions handled when a UE roams out of its home network?
column2: Emergency services shall not be provided by the home network, and if the UE has sufficient credentials, it shall initiate an emergency registration with the roamed-to network.

column1: What information should the IMS core network be able to transport in an emergency session?
column2: The IMS core network shall be able to transport information on the location of the subscriber.

column1: What is the additional CSCF role introduced in the IMS architecture, as specified in TS 23.002 [12]?
